reviewText:
Score
10/10  Praise the Sun!


Too Long Didn't Read
Graphics improvements are just the icing on the cake.  The real reason to upgrade or buy Dark Souls II: Scholar of the First Sin is for the drastically improved  core content  and  game flow.  DLC and Scholar Bonus content are worked into the game more naturally.  Many issues the community had with the design have been attempted to be addressed via drastic layout changes.

Detailed Review

The Controversy
Dark Souls II: Scholar of the First Sin is a new rendition of Dark Souls II.

There are three major complaints the community had with this new version that I'd like to address:

This is just a minor graphical update that the PC could've handled originally (DirectX 11)

The Dark Souls II community would be split apart on two separate servers.  The old DirectX 9 server and the new DirectX 11 server.

The 60 FPS durability bug. *Update*
The Developers have acknowledged the durability bug and are planning a fix.

Source: http://info.darksouls.jp/other/pc/information_detail/2015-04-16-01.html
Although the existence of this game does split the community, the cost of upgrading for exisiting users is offered at a substantial discount:
$20 for owners of the previous game who also had the DLC
$30 for owners of the previous game who do not own the DLC

The cost to upgrade is pretty small considering the massive amount of time many players spend playing these Souls games (500+ hours isn't too uncommon).  Multiplayer is very active at pretty much all levels of play at this point on the DirectX 11 version.

A comment on the community split
If you're having problems with finding multiplayer on the DirectX9 version, I'd definitely recommend considering the upgrade, especially for PC users.  The entire community could arguably reunite and stick with the DirectX11 version.  It's not expensive and the changes have added variety and a much more fair challenge to all of the game's core areas.

If you're worried about having to make a new character and start from scratch, I guarantee you it won't take as long as you think.  You might even enjoy the fresh new playthrough(s) as much as I have.

A comment on the graphics:
The contrast between light and dark has improved.  Torches and spell effects look better.  This is not the reason to get the game though.


The Real Reason to buy or upgrade to Scholar of the First Sin
Many forum posts I read discussing this game were very focused on the DirectX11 graphics and how this game was just reselling slightly upgraded graphics and nothing else.

The real reason to pick up this new version is for the massive amount of changes made to the core adventure.  What do I mean?

*Semi-Spoilers*
The developers/designers have stepped through every single area in the original game and made massive revisions to:

Placement, amount and type of enemies.  You'll find new, area appropriate enemies all over the place that weren't originally there before.

Some enemies have been removed or reduced from their original locations entirely.

There are some new NPCs you can summon to your aid that are running some pretty cool builds.  The placement of some old NPC summon signs have also been adjusted to make those NPCs more useful in their respective areas.

Many Major items and upgrades have been moved around drastically.

Barriers are erected in areas you wouldn't expect.

Shortcuts added in other places.

Thankfully this version removes the free preorder bonus weapons that are automatically handed out to every character you create (making starting equipment slightly more meaningful).  Don't worry, they can still be purchased for souls at a certain vendor, deeper within the game.

The DLC areas can't just be immediately accessed for free any more.  You must earn the right to enter each DLC area by finding the appropriate keys in very lore appropriate locations within the game.

Many, Many, new invasions.  Some of which are random.
The actual line-by-line changelist for Scholar of the First Sin is so massive that it would take too long for me to list it all here.

Just know that every area that is not part of the DLC has undergone substantial changes.

You should just experience it for yourself.  Reddit was trying to list all of the changes and the list just runs for pages long.


What do all these changes mean?
If all you wanted out of a Souls game is the story and you've played Dark Souls II already, there's nothing new to see here. (Unless you haven't played the DLC and the Scholar content...)

If you like Dark Souls for the adventure, the multiplayer and the encounters though, this update is definitely for you.  The revisions made to this game result in an extremely polished gameplay experience.

It's very obvious that careful thought was put into these revisions to make certain areas more enjoyable to play through.

Scholar of the First Sin was more fun to play through than the DirectX 9 version as a result of these content changes.


The DLC: The Lost Crowns + the Scholar of the First Sin Bonus Content
Quick note on the DLC since there are some people who may have played the main game but not the DLC yet.

The DLC has excellent level design / bosses and supplements the story very well.  Each area also introduces some really cool and unique equipment that can help spruce up your character's fighting style or utility.  The designers may have very well used what they learned from building the DLC to help make the original game flow better.

Ultimately, Scholar of the First Sin does a great job at  naturally  working the DLC and Scholar Bonus content into the game in a way that feels natural.  They don't feel tacked on like in the DirectX9 version.



When you look at this new game as a whole, it offers a gargantuan amount of real estate to explore, co-op and pvp in.  Many of the changes that were made to the game, could only have been made after analyzing the community response to the original version of Dark Souls II and watching how regular users play the game via online streams.

Tremendous Value, Highest Recommendation

reviewText:
'Are you the next monarch? Orâ€¦ merely a pawn of fate?â€˜The Emerald Herald
__________________________________________

Introduction
The 'Soul' series is known for harsh difficulty and rewarding gameplay in which dying is mostly the players' own fault for making a wrong move at the wrong time.

In difference to many modern RPGs the lore is kind of hidden as well as it's neither presented in amazing cutscenes nor illuminated from every perspective.
The player has to actually read dialogues and item descriptions, revealing piece by piece of the backgrounds and the story.

In 'Dark Souls II' the main recipe of the series stays the same: A lonesome traveler in a kingdom (haunted by an undead curse) starts a journey full of fighting, exploring and dying. The player will get crushed by hammers and axes, pierced by spears and arrows, cut by daggers and swords, melted by fireballs, cursed by hexes-... there are definitely lots of ways to die and you have to face all of them if you want to survive and see the end of your journey.

There are many negative aspects that stick to 'Dark Souls II' since its release. Many of them are still somewhat present but with the three DLCs, the 'SOTFS' edition and several patches many aspects have changed. I don't want to make another huge review about the game's content (you could easily fill several pages about lore, characters and stuff), so I'll make it 'short' (well okay - it's still quite long) and focus on some main points that bothered me in many reviews.
__________________________________________

Some say the game is too easy compared to 'Demon's Souls' or 'Dark Souls'â€¦
The changed enemy positions in the 'SOTFS' edition and the great levels of the DLCs shall provide some nice challenging experiences for anybody. From my point of view the difficulty level has the right balance between 'challengingâ€˜ and 'frustratingâ€˜. Sure there are some annoying parts, some ganking and some cheap deaths, but it never feels too easy or so hard that I think I may never be able to do it. Even the 'Fume Knight' and the 'Frigid Outskirts' are manageable. And for players who still think it's a piece of cake: Fortunately there is a convenant for you mad ones that increases the overall difficulty even more.
__________________________________________

Some say the game is uglyâ€¦
The 'Soul' series was never known for the best graphics of the generation but all the time the overall picture was great and the 'charming' atmosphere made you forget about some of these muddy textures. 'Dark Souls II: SOTFS' is not breaking with this 'rule' but the improved graphics of the 'SOTFS' edition are definitely a good improvement and especially armors are now very detailled. (However with texture modding and ENB and stuff you were able to get nearly the same results out of the original 'Dark Souls II')

The varied landscape in combination with huge buildings and massive monuments of the past (and several nice particle effects) really creates some admirable places where you are able to forget the hopelessness of your journey and immerge into Drangleic â€“ at least until an invader stabs you.
__________________________________________

Some say the game is not worthy of the 'Souls' series as it feels empty and without the special feeling of its precursors...
They say it's no real 'Souls' game, just something else. Sure itâ€™s neither Allant nor Gwyn, neither Boletaria nor Lordran. However Drangleic has several memorable moments, names and characters as well. The story and the lore are atmospheric and well done and I get nearly the same feeling as in the other games. Especially the DLC stories and areas are totally brilliant. They could be imagined as different Archstones and small parts of the world that create an exquisite overall picture, be it the Brume Tower or Frozen Eleum Loyce.
__________________________________________

I'm a huge fan of the 'Soulsâ€˜ series and I've spent several hundreds of hours in the different games: Iâ€˜ve visited Boletaria and fought with King Allant, walked in the Valley of Defilement and felt like a demon myself after killing Garl Vinland and the Saint Astraea. Iâ€™ve travelled through the holy city of Anor Londo, met the former Lord of Sunlight and brought peace to the legendary knight Artorias and the darkness known as Manus in a time and world long forgotten...

The 'Souls' games were always full of memorable moments and from my point of view 'Dark Souls II' is no exception in this category: On the top of the castle I fought the Mirror Knight under a rainy sky, Iâ€™ve challenged the proud samurai Sir Alonne in a duel and travelled to a castle sunken in a sea of fire - At the end I was finally able to meet a king who has lost everything.
It was definitely a remarkable journey.
__________________________________________

Cons
In comparison to the precursors some decisions and changes aren't entirely positive, like e.g. the high amount of bonfires, the immediate teleportation ability or the simplified upgrade system. Some parts of this old 'gloomy desperation' and helplessness that haunted you in the other games are missing - but there are also positive changes that improve the gaming experience: The 'SL1 invader twinks', the 'Dark Wood Grain Ring' rolling (a.k.a. the Ninja Flip) and the lag-stabbing insanity of 'Dark Souls' are nearly gone, respecing your character is now possible and the sheer amount of different weapons, spells, armors and items (Fashion Souls!) is simply amazing and enables many different builds and styles. In addition some of the items that had to be farmed for long hours in the Original 'Dark Souls II' (e.g. Visible Aurous Set) can now be aquired more easily in chests and treasures.

And above all... since 'Dark Souls II' the game finally features beards - praise the sun for this milestone! \[T]/
__________________________________________

Conclusion
From my point of view make the changes of the 'SOTFS'-Edition the games' atmosphere and lore more coherent and provide challenging new fights and changed enemy positions.
The DLCs of 'Dark Souls II' are simply amazing and provide exactly what Souls veterans are looking for: fantastic levels with shortcuts and hidden paths, new interesting stories with remarkable characters and challenges from which even the toughest veteran may burst into tears.

Still 'Dark Souls IIâ€˜ is not perfect and overall more a Titanite Chunk than a Titanite Slab. However itâ€™s still damn good and keeps me interested even after over 100 hours. Itâ€™s probably an 8.5 out of 10 - well at least if your nerves and your will are strong enough.

So in the endâ€¦ it is time to meet your fate Bearer of the Curse. Take a last look at the bonfire, your last anchor in this sea of darkness. Pick up your sword and your shield and move on into the unknown. And never forget your Estus flaskâ€¦

...youâ€™ll need it. Trust me.

EDIT: Please note that while I don't have too many hours logged on steam, I played a PS4 version up to Dragon Shrine.

Would I recommend this game? Yes, and no. Depends on the person I'm talking to, really. So here's what I think:

You should get Dark Souls II: SotFS edition if:

* You don't own Dark Souls 2 but think you want to play it.
* You own Dark Souls 2, but none of the DLCs.
* You are a huge Souls/DkS 2 fan and want to get every last game and version.
* You play Dark Souls 2 mainly for the PVP/coop.
* You're interested in trying the Souls games for the first time, but not quite sure what to pick. You're not willing to spend 5 minutes looking for, and installing a 3rd party patch to make a poor PC-port(Dark Souls 1) tolerable.

You shouldn't get Dark Souls II: SotFS edition if:

* You have Dark Souls 2 and the DLCs already, and aren't interested in the PVP/COOP aspects too much.
* You have Dark Souls 2, but don't enjoy it too much because you feel it can't quite fill the boots of Dark Souls 1. This version of Dark Souls 2 will not fix your issues. It will make Dark Souls 2 even more, well, Dark Souls 2.
* You are new and interested in the Souls games, but not quite sure what to pick. Looking for, and installing a 3rd party patch to make the poor Dark Souls 1 pc-port enjoyable is not a big deal for you.

I own the original Dark Souls 2 + all the DLCs, and have played through them multiple times. I personally think the changes to the graphics and gameplay of vanilla Dark Souls 2 were absolutely not worth the 15â‚¬ price I had to pay. reviewText:
Dark Souls II: Scholar of the First Sin is such an insanely rich and expansive game; FromSoft could have released two separate games. Which is kind of what they did.

Back when Dark Souls II was first released people considered it a hollow and bleak follow up to the original Dark Souls, me included. However it wasnâ€™t without its high points and strengths. FromSoft took much criticism to heart and released three DLC packs with an incredible amount of content in each to offset some of the lacklustre areas from the main game, as well adding several elements that pad up the lacking story somewhat. They wrapped it all up in a new graphics package, slapped a full price tag on it and flung it back onto the selves. A gutsy strategy, but the game is better for it. The game is an immersive role-playing monster that keeps sucking you in. Furthermore, it has an insane amount of options and content to explore and exploit. Finally, it retools and refines many of its predecessorâ€™s aspects. Dark Souls II is a behemoth of a game that merits any self-respecting gamerâ€™s attention.

Dark Souls II picks up thousands of years after the original Dark Souls and continuously throws you down a well of unyielding challenges and adversity with the express purpose of hardening you for the next battle. The original world of Dark Souls is gone and in its place is a dilapidated, nearly abandoned kingdom called Drangleic. You are an undead, who ventures to this land to find a cure for your, and your familyâ€™s hollowing condition. The game sets of off with the bare minimum, as is a staple of the FromSoft narrative style. Youâ€™re forced to discover the bulk of the story for yourself. This is where the developers went overboard. Instead of hiding plot and infusing it with delicious lore, they now provide you with the bare minimum of plot and nearly drown you in lore. Admittedly, the lore of Dark Souls II is incredible and novels could be written on its depth and enriching character. However, the lack of apparent plot rather withholds you from thoroughly exploring it. You, as the player, are not motivated to investigate items, characters, or world as explore. The only thing youâ€™re told a few minutes in is to â€œseek the kingâ€. When you eventually do find the man in question heâ€™ll tell you to seek adversity. Finally facing the final boss is punctuated with a resounding â€œwhat the hell was that?â€
The thing is, that when you finally discard the narrativeâ€™s notions, and do explore on your own accord, youâ€™ll be rewarded immensely. It seems almost as if FromSoft did not just want to make the gameplay difficult, but also the story. The Scholar of the First Sin edition provides some context to the ordeal, but youâ€™re mostly left to your own devices in terms of plot direction and interpretation.
While the story may not be too captivating, the general gameplay is thoroughly addictive. It is common knowledge at this point that the Souls series are difficult. The difficulty spike from other games requires you to learn and to invest effort. The eventual successes after many a loss will feel monumental. This risk reward structure is enthralling to say the least. Not only do you earn valuable progress, but also experience and valuable items to customise your character and playstyle.

Dark Souls II is a genuinely personal experience, and the game offers you near countless tools to differentiate and customise your experience. While the game does force you to picks a class at the very beginning, you easily deviate from your initial resume. From the starting area the world lies open at your feet. Hundreds of weapons to try. Dozens of armours to wear. Loads of magic spells to learn. Zounds of monsters to slay. The game lends itself to all manners of play. You can play a buffed out tank and brave hordes in plate mail. Or stay lithe and swift and put out ludicrous amounts of damage. Physical matter not your thing? The try the magic arsenal. We have lighting, darkness, fire, and poison; even this blue stuff that just kills things. You can have it any way you want, and hardly any play through will be the same. There are even special weapons that combine the styles. The insane degree to which you can adjust, mix and match makes for some incredible fidelity. It is therefore good that the game also has a respec button to mulligan your build when you see fit.
However, it is important that your stomping grounds for your personal build is well tilled, and unfortunately, that is not always the case in Dark Souls II. While character tools are amazing, the level design is somewhat lacking. Rather washed-out areas and straight corridor stages make up the majority of world. A true shame, because the original Dark Souls and its predecessor Demonsâ€™ Souls all had environments that were maze like and harrowing to traverse. Making it to the short cut in the old games was a relief. In Dark Souls II itâ€™s just a convenience. This issue is mostly resolved in the three DLC areas that send you into completely disorienting maze like tombs, towers and cities to fight even deadlier enemies, but also find even more and better loot.

From a technical standpoint, Dark Souls II addresses many complaints from its predecessors, but also introduces some new, and unwelcome changes. Praise be to the sun when the backstab got nerfed. Praise be to Vendrick when the online connection now takes place via dedicated servers instead of P2P. Hail to the crowns for the new dual wield animations that allow for the amazing samurai, ninja and berserker builds that flay and destroy the many bosses. Dark Souls II has taken care to make good on several sigmatic issues with the original, and FromSoft has succeeded in most cases. The result is a more playable and durable system that is more manageable to use.
On the flipside though, the game introduces a stat called soul memory to govern the interaction between players. It basically changes the thresholds for cooperation and invasions from level based to purely experience based. This skews to balance to nearly ridiculous levels where proper online play becomes extremely hard or downright non-existent until you manage to reach a later section of the game where you may or may not fit in. Furthermore, boss design, the Soulsâ€™ series great pride, has taken a hit. Most bosses are souped up guys in armour with broken tracking and disjointed hitboxes. The number of monstrosities that do show up are hardly a challenge. Some fights against these blood knights are extremely amazing, but the majority is forgettable. Once again, the DLC bosses fix this issue to a great extent.
In general, enemy design is based on â€œguys in armour.â€ What is even worse is that FromSoft decided to just go for the horde approach when it came to enemy placement and difficulty tweaks. When you die itâ€™s either due to a horde of cheap, enemies, or one enemy with infallible tracking on its weapon. The Scholar version addresses this with amended enemy placement, but the damage is already done.

Despite some shortcomings, the overwhelming amount of content, immersion and options ultimately make Dark Souls II a main course on any video game dinner menu. The meaty length and beefy options allow for a multitude of approaches that can fit anyoneâ€™s playstyle. While the story doesnâ€™t flavour the dish too much, the underlying textures provide a distinct taste that will have to dig in a little deeper. Although the chefâ€™s final changes may divide the guests on what wine goes best with it, at the end of it, youâ€™ll be satisfied and well fed.

Some people cry that Dark Souls 2 is ultra mega hard, but in my opinion it's easier than DS 1 and like in 1 in 2 all you need to do is not give up, find your motivation and move forward. You will die and lose anyway doesn't matter how powerfull and pro you think you are. If you don't believe me, then go and try PvP.

Now I will try to sum up by making list of some cons and pros.

Pros:
- even when you beat all bosses and watch credits you can still play this game,
- many, many different armors and weapons which can be upgraded, everyoneone will find weapon he enjoy (in, let's call it 'late game' of course),
- bosses looks very effective and they are real challenge like they should be even if you summon other players for help,
- covenants makes game more interesting (especially Company of Champions),
- rumors say that maximum level is 838,

- sometimes makes you satisfied,

Cons:

- sometimes playing this game is just waste of time (trying kill boss 2 hours and fail),

- MESSAGES  2 centimeters from Illusory Walls so you can't 'open' them,

- cheaters,
- sometimes PvP is not possible because of servers,

I recommend that game to everyone who have time and who is looking for challenges. This game is not for everyone and  I guess that's why I had so much fun when I learned how to play good, after hundreds deaths.

reviewText:
Dark Souls 2 takes pretty much everything good from dark souls 1, and throws it in the trash.

Then it takes that trash and cleans it up a bit, puts it on display and sticks a bunch of extra stuff on it with duct tape, you don't really want it nor is it necessary, but it isn't bad.

What I mean to say is, the game is fun, there's about 3 times as much content as dark souls 1, but it's not quite as well thought out as dark souls 1.

The world is about as cohesive as an M.C. Escher painting, but each location individually looks good. The weapons and armor are extremely numerous and varied. There is an insane amount of magic spells in the game as well. The online connectivity is far more reliable than the first game.

There are a few technical changes from dark souls 1 that you might not like if you're really attached to the first game. Estus drinking is slower, stamina regenerates slower, the stats are different and backstabs/ripostes are not instant. The graphics are improved though slightly different style than the first game. 60 fps, which makes the game feel a lot more responsive.

The only complaint I have is the new stat adaptability, you need to level it to increase the invincibility length on your rolls or else you won't be able to dodge very effectively.

Basically it's a change from the first game, and whether you like the new stats or not, the fact is this game offers way more content, customization and technical improvements across the board compared to the first.

reviewText:
I've been bored for quite awhile.
Most of the games I have, I either had played out several times already, or wasn't interested in.
Bought plenty o' mediocre games which I regretted after the first few hours of gameplay.
Honestly, for some time I thought if most devs were even trying at all anymore.
Unfinished products being sold on steam which never get finished. Empty promises, poor design, etc.

Then I stumbled across this spiked, polished gem.
I had heard alot about the Dark Souls franchise but never really gave it a go, so when Steam held a sale and Dark Souls was in it I figured why not.

It's been ATLEAST 4 years since I've been this excited about a game and dragged along into it's lore.
The sheer detail of the story Dark Souls offers aside from the marvelous combat is amazing, if you're willing to venture out and catch up on it that is.
If the lore does not interest you, then that doesn't matter because Dark Souls 2 doesn't neccesarily need you to know it's story, though it's handy to listen even if you're not interested. NPC's can sometimes give hints or help out if you get stuck and don't know what to do.

The good:

- Though I have not played Dark Souls 1, I had no problem with following the story. Dark Souls 2 continues a thousand years after Dark Souls 1.

Once you begin digging, all sorts of questions pop up about the true nature of the world around you.


- The combat is so mind-boggling that it took me several hours to grasp it's design.
Instead of most RPG's where you don't really care about your stamina untill it's so low you should already be worrying, Dark Souls takes it a different swing. Easily switch from 1H to 2H which have their own benifits and bad perks.
Alot of weapons also have different movesets so almost every weapon you find is an entirely new way of handling combat.

- PvE is purely focused on rational thinking, timing and remembering the patterns and movesets of your enemy. Be it a minion, or boss. So don't expect to win by continously spamming R1.

reviewText:
After completing Dark Souls, I found myself extremely satisfied - it was a solid RPG, with very well-designed levels and mostly fantastic game mechanics. I also, however, wanted more, so I decided to wait until the inevitable full-package of the second game. Fast forward quite a while, and I'm playing Dark Souls II: Scholar of the First Sin. I haven't completed the game yet (I will, of course, though), but I have been so frustrated by the combination of a number of problems (some larger than others) that I have been urging myself to write a review for this game. It was one specific area from one of the DLC sections that pushed me over the edge (I won't detail anything too much as I don't want to spoil the game for anyone wishing to play it).

My first complaint with the game is the clear design decision for the team to focus on making the game difficult. While Dark Souls was extremely well designed in most respects, with mostly balanced enemies and the only difficulty stemming from the player's faults, the second game has enemies and areas specifically designed to frustrate and kill you. Bandai Namco clearly wanted to play on the popularity of Dark Souls as a 'difficult' game, with the marketing and even the intro of the game being focused on how much you're going to die, and the team at From Software working on this game clearly misunderstood the principles of its predecessors. While the game plays best with enemies being encountered sequentially (due to the nature of the game's combat), Dark Souls II seems all too keen to throw hand-fulls of enemies into your path for seemingly no reason. While a single enemy (or two at most) would usually be fine to tackle due to its moveset being based on the requirement to dodge its attacks, it's common in Dark Souls II to find four or five moderately-difficult enemies running at you, obviously promoting the 'lame it out' tactic or a slug fest. This is only emphasised by the game's focus on bosses having additional summons - they don't make the bosses any more interesting, just less fair and more frustrating. Yes, Dark Souls did have multiple simultaneous enemies at various points, but they'd usually be balanced by having low health, low damage outputs or predictable movesets, making the encounters much more fair and fun than the frustrating encounters of Dark Souls II. Not only are encounters frustrating when they involve a needless plethora of enemies, but one-on-one encounters have been ruined by every enemy's tendency to automatically track the position of the player at all times. While an enemy is charging up an overhead attack or sprinting towards you, they'll usually slide idiotically across the ground so that their move is guaranteed to connect with you. This becomes ridiculous when the hit-boxes of several moves are much wider than the moves themselves, probably due to clumsy implementation. I should also point out that a lot of enemies have too many defensive options, to the point at which the only option for a slow-attacking character is to wait for an opening, put in a single hit, then wait again. This is because many enemies have a frustrating combination of having wide swings, fast movement, no wake-up or cool-down time or extremely high poise. Pair this with the frustrating auto-tracking, and the game is practically telling you to 'lame it out'. The difficulty with a lot of the bosses isn't the boss itself, but the urge to get an extra hit in that will result in just getting hit. In some cases, if you do get that extra hit in but need to roll away immediately, what would have been a successful roll in the previous game becomes useless, as the enemy will just change their attack direction to face your new position, or even catch the air around you and cause damage without actually hitting you.

This brings me onto my next point - a number of the game's mechanics have been completely screwed-up for absolutely no reason. My earlier point about attempts to roll away from an enemy's attack being almost futile is only enforced by how much the invincibility frames of rolling have been ruined. I found the old rolling and Equip Load system of the first game to be fine, so I am baffled that they managed to ruin rolling so much with their new Agility-skill-based system. Now, what would have been a safe roll in Dark Souls results in getting hit anyway in Dark Souls II. There are far less invincibility frames than before, so the unreliability only makes the game more frustrating. If I successfully dodge an attack in a game, I would usually be rewarded by not taking any damage, rather than just getting hit anyway. Then, the new backstab system feels very clumsily implemented - when I am trying to swing my sword a few feet behind someone, the game will instead make the character attempt a backstab (and, obviously, fail due to the distance). This wasn't the case in the last game, as the backstabbing animation would only trigger upon a successful backstab. When I'm fighting enemies, I shouldn't be in a position where I am fighting the controls as well. Then, there's the point of the healing system. The Estus Flask system of Dark Souls was absolutely fine - players had a reasonable number of consumable health potions, called Estus, that could be refilled at bonfires (which were usually very distant from each other), but had to maintain a good amount of Estus Flasks for use in boss fights as well, which were usually quite a way away from the last bonfire. Now, the player can just buy an infinite amount of additional health items called Lifegems, which heal slower and less than Estus Flasks, but can be carried in an enormous max. quantity of 99 at a time. When paired with an increase in the amount of bonfires to refill the Estus Flask, the availability of health items is no longer a problem. I am seriously confused as to why the developers felt like the system needed changing, as it worked extremely well in the last game.

Finally, I have a massive problem with the general laziness of the game's design. In the last game, areas were large and complex, with single bonfires to cover most areas, many directions to go in and a large focus on opening shortcuts to make the path from the bonfire to the boss easier. It is also very important to note that the world of Lordran in Dark Souls was interconnected, with a main hub called the Firelink Shrine and routes back to the shrine being opened up from the areas that the player visits. The world of Drangleic in Dark Souls II, on the other hand, consists of a series of corridors in comparison. The game's attempt at a hub area, called Majula, branches off to a few other locations, but only really acts as a headquarters of sorts for the player, rather than a meeting point to loop back to. Areas usually end in dead-ends, and rather than looping the areas around in a clever way the developers made it so that the player can teleport between any bonfires from the offset, of which there are far too many (some areas have five or six bonfires, which is ridiculous). So, the reward for defeating a large boss is often the option to just teleport back to Majula, rather than explore a new area. Not only is the world completely disjointed, but it doesn't even make sense at times. I won't spoil any locations, but the impossible space in a few of the areas is so dumb that the realisation of how stupid it really is breaks any sense of immersion. This is the same for a couple of progression blockers, but I won't go into detail. Not only are the areas lazily designed, but the enemies are too - most enemies are humanoid, even if it would make for sense for them not to be, and too many (including bosses) are simply large humanoids with big weapons and similar movesets. Rather than mixing up the boss designs, they are often just given additional enemies to spice up the fight, usually resulting in more frustrating bosses that, again, promote 'laming it out' tactics. I've run out of characters.

reviewText:
Light this bonfire and rest a while with me.

I got this (upgrade version) free from a friend, we have something akin to 1000 DS2 hours between us on various platforms so have basically played the Souls series to death. (don't take my 'played' time as a given on Steam).

Let's get the bad stuff out of the way first, and maybe add a sprinkling of good stuff too, just for balance.

Most, if not all of the bugs and glitches from the original are still here, including the 2x durability loss bug that occurs at 60fps.

My musings:

The much touted graphical changes aren't really an upgrade, just a few tweaks to lighting (makes some areas a little darker or a little lighter but not much else), and textures (SLIGHTLY less muddy than vanilla).

The gameplay remains the same as vanilla too apart from slightly different enemy locations (some actually make more sense within their respective levels now) and unfortunately a ton more gank squads.

Personally I've never been a fan of artificial difficulty with regards to placing more and more enemies in an area to ramp up the difficulty, I would call this lazy and uninspired to the nth degree, totally shameful.  I would much rather have less enemies to fight but in more interesting and dangerous locations, for example, fighting a 2-hand weilder on a narrow bridge with no rails over a sheer drop, or an archer in a tight coridoor etc.

The durability bug is the deal breaker for me though, it's been there from the start and FS have done NOTHING to even address it, even after all the exposure it's had. It's like FS live in this tiny bubble that no outside influence can penetrate.  It's disheartening to the extreme, especially as Bloodborne is so much better in this respect than DS2 will ever be due to B-team's lack of care and attention.

There's no doubting that DS2 is fun, but, for me, not for the right reasons and the same thing applies to Scholar.

If you don't own Dark Souls 2, or own it but NOT the DLC then this is an ideal purchase.
If however, you own Dark Souls 2 AND the DLC avoid like the plague, as for my money, this hasn't enough changes to justify being paid content, only a cash-grab from a severely floundering B-team.

reviewText:
If you're like me, and were holding out on getting the dlc's from a holiday sale that never came, go ahead and get this version. If you're new to the game, I'd also recommend getting this version (but perhaps after playing Dark Souls 1).

If you already own the original with all dlc's I wouldn't recommend the upgrade at the asking price. Aside from some asset shuffling (enemies, items, etc.) and some really minor geometry changes, there isn't a whole lot of difference between this and a modded DX9 version.

Wait for a sale.





About the game itself:

400+ hours with the original base game, I can tell you I think the game is fun, but fun doesn't make it good.

Cons:

Some of the design is poorly done, some of the art is incredibly lazy, the story is all over the place with far too many vague references to the first game, online play has frustrating latency, and the matchmaking while implemented with good intentions is broken.

Pros:

The character models/textures are fantastic, the soundscape is immersive and the voice acting superb. The animations are more fluid than previous 'Souls' games leading to tighter character control, which, in a game as focused on the action and timing as this, makes it a joy to explore the many and varied environments the game offers.



45+ hours into the 'upgraded' content:

The 'enhanced' graphics seems like it's only for lighting and some bloom. The textures don't seem to have been touched, or at least not the terrible ones I've noticed. They did make clever use of the lighting effects and using torches as triggers though.

The enemy/item shuffling, at least in New Game, isn't too surprising or even that challenging as they are the same enemies that were always in the game.  It is kind of refreshing to find that The Pursuer actually pursues, and at least the item shuffling gives a reason to explore the same old areas again.

Not much for new content that I've found so far, some 'new' npc invaders one which actually has new acquirable equipment. I haven't gotten through the DLC's yet, though I couldn't comment on whether they had any content added or not.

reviewText:
I was invaded in the bastille by a guy using a spear without the requirements for it.
I was using a joke character inspired by Majela ZeZe Diamond, naked with a weak whip.
He was using a character with all the facial sliders turned up.
Gaily we played, rolling around poking and whipping one another, until I came out the victor.
The same chap invaded me not too long afterwards and watched as I managed to parry the persuer to death.
Upon my victory he rewarded me with treats before diving into the waters below.
That's the kind of fun time you can have with this game.

In comparison to the vanilla versions (x360 ps3 dx9), things have changed a lot. Areas have better and often more sensical/lore friendly enemy placements and the game feels a lot less empty. General progression is much more fluid in contrast to the game's general difficulty increase; vanilla may have been easier, but having to reach Iron Keep just to get the dull ember, or having to go through the Belfry Luna just to get the bastille key were a pain. In Scholar of the First Sin, these items exist in their appropriate areas.

I haven't finished Scholar just yet, but it already feels like the definitive version. General difficulty improvements and bug fixes are implemented from the get-go and the difficulty increase of the PvE experience never feels too over the top. There are more NPC summons in place to prevent people getting too stuck in certain areas after the game dies, NPCs appear in stranger places, sometimes more appropriate ones. A few hiccups remain from the conversion to 60fps, however, including some erratic movement from enemies that may attack far too quickly for you to parry, although capping your framerate somehow will fix these issues.

It still has the same problem Dark Souls 2 and 3 have - coming from the original Dark Souls, where poise was a gamekiller and parrying was almost a necessity, DS2 and 3 feel much easier and harder, allowing for viable dex builds and with less enemies having crazy amounts of poise, but parrying has been made a much more difficult and often pointless endeavour that is hard to drill out from your mind. The games went from a slow and clunky mess where parrying and poise breaking caused you to min/max and optimize, to a much more fluid game where dual wielding isn't awful and all weapons feel impactful, although some have their niche appeal.

It's a hack and slash, now.

But after all that, it's still Dark Souls, just with a roll that isn't locked to four directions upon locking on, and with more friendliness towards fashion or whatever you specifically want to use, without the instant backstabs or the horrendous lag. People's main complaint come from the fact that it isn't a direct sequel. That's part of what makes DS2's story so great. To quote Arin Hanson of GameGrumps regarding these games: You just go." That's precisely what DS2's story and level design is about. You aren't supposed to be clear on anything

reviewText:
If you haven't played the original release of Dark Souls II, then my recommendation is a BIG RECOMMENDED. If you have played the original and are thinking about buying this re-release then you can read on.
SPOILERS AHEAD!

The good:

- The lighting in this game is better because now you actually need torches to be able to see in some dark areas (The Gutter).
- Invading and Co-Op NPCs are much better and feel more alive. Hell, they're even mocking you if they manage to kill you and they also have other surprises ready for youâ€¦
- Better enemy placement: In some areas the enemy placement makes more sense lore wise and gameplay wise.

The bad:

- Some areas have become optional or even meaningless. Exp: Before you had to kill the Gargoyles to get the key to light the fires in the Lost Sinner boss room. Now you conveniently find the key on your way to the Lost Sinner. Where I have to ask myself: Why do we even take the hassle now to kill them? There is no real rewards for them anymore. They even made Dragons Aerie optional, why?
- Better graphics are not that noticeable for the most part and where they could have improved the graphics by simply improving the details (or even adding any details at all! I'm looking at you, Forest of Fallen Giants King's Door courtyard) they didn't.
- Enemy placement (again): What is a good point for Dark Souls II: SotFS is also a negative point. In some areas the new enemy placement is ridiculous! To a point where it is plain annoying and not really harder. I'm looking at you Heide's Tower of Flames.
- Arbitrary road blocks: Now you have petrified statues everywhere and quite often they don't even make any sense from a lore perspective.

The game is still awesome in it's own right but I simply think in comparison to the original a downgrade. Still I will manly play this version now as it will probably be the reference point for Dark Souls II discussions in the futureâ€¦

reviewText:
First, let me address the controversy surrounding Scholar of the First Sin. If you want to skip this bit, the actual review starts in paragraph five. Dark Souls II came out about a year ago. The graphics in the trailer looked better than the in-game graphics. People were upset, as if this was some new affront to gamers everywhere. Then people played the game, decided they really liked it, and the world spun on.

Fast forward a few months and From Software announces a new version of the game called Scholar of the First Sin. It includes updated graphics, support for more simultaneous multiplayer connections, extra NPCs for both lore and combat, revised enemy placement, a new boss, and an alternate ending. Furthermore, most of this content will be available as a free update to current Dark Souls II owners.

The updated graphical engine (DX11) was incompatible with the old engine (DX9). Thus, rather than replace the old engine entirely, they decided to release the DX11 version of Scholar of the First Sin as a standalone paid upgrade. As a bonus, they included all the DLC.

So what are people complaining about? What's the controversy? People are upset about paying $20 for what they percieve as a graphical patch. In reality, the DX11 version contains the revised troop placement, allows for up to six people to play simultaneously, and yes, is also a graphical upgrade.

What about the game, though? Isn't this a review? Yes, yes it is.

Scholar of the First Sin is great fun to play. If you played Dark Souls II, you'll enjoy the new enemy placement. It does two things very well. First, the new placement shakes things up. Enemies aren't where you expect them to be anymore, so even for veteran DS2 players, each map is a new experience. Secondly, the new placement is more devious. Harder enemies appear sooner, many others have better placement, and you'll find yourself panicking more than you did the first time, which is a welcome change. Dark Souls II was easier than its predecessor, and the new enemy placement in Scholar addresses that problem. Perfectly? No - but I'm happy with the results.

Extra players in multiplayer is a blast. Four person boss assaults are both fun and hilarious, and fight club on the bridge just got a whole lot messier.

The graphical differences don't immediately pop out at you since many textures look the same. But having played for a while now, I've found myself stopping on multiple occasions because I just happened to notice that the horizon was a lot more pretty, that fire now illuminates the things around it, that metal reflects light the way you'd expect it to, and that sometimes god-rays are a nice addition to a scene.

Something else I want to address but can't put my finger on - the game feels better. I don't know if they optimized the engine, or if the controls are slightly more responsive or what, but the whole experience is more comfortble. I realize this point is entirely without solid evidence, but I felt it worth mentioning.

So to those of you who own Dark Souls II and all it's DLC, I think this game is worth picking up. It's a fresh take on something we love. Oh, and they got rid of that miserable preorder bonus gear.

To those of you who don't own Dark Souls II but want it, get Scholar of the First Sin. It comes with all the DLC, and you'll never have to know why the first four paragraphs were written.

reviewText:
***WARNING: CONTAINS SOME SPOILERS. Probably.***
All spoilers are covered by spoiler tag, if you haven't noticed yet. So yeah. If you spoil something for yourself, blame curiousity.

So, after seeing a lot of disappointed negative reviews, claiming that the Scholar of the First Sin was the worst thing since the infamous E.T., I've decided to buy it and find out myself.

But first things first. I live in Russia and prices are pretty much localized here, so I've got my upgrage (I own all of the DLCs) for hillarious 5$. Was I disappoint? Well, find out yourself:

GRAPHICS:
That's what the biggest complaints have been about. People claim that there are no improvements, and that they'd rather stick with free GeDoSaTo and the original game. Here's what I saw.

There really is only one thing that didn't get a graphical update. World textures. While it is rather disappointing, the SotFS really made it up by the use of lighting. I was really shocked to see the beautiful use of lighting in Things Betwixt and Majula, and it continues to impresses me still, even though I've progressed a lot in my very first SotFS save. They've made a great job making some sort of 'artificial darkness' that vanishes away as soon as you get a torch. Finally we've got a chance of seeing this 'perception vs. safety' feature we've been excited about before DkSII came out. Character textures seem to be improved a lot, as my character's face looked far more detailed on the creation screen and in the game itself. But really the biggest improvement has been made with *particle effects*. Yeah, you've read this correct. SotFS improves on particle effects such as souls, sparks, Pursuer's eyes and so on.

Graphic improvement is 7/10

ENEMY PLACEMENTS, IMMERSION, GAME PACE:
Many many more Pursuer encounters, and these are rather unexpected. Now the guy really pursues you. Every Pursuer except the first one drops Twinkling Titanite, making a good early game source of it. Also, there are a lot more enemies in stages, but I didn't feel overwhelmed. It is impossible to run through now as well, so SotFS seems to fix all the problems original DkSII had with enemy placement and AI. There are a lot of things that add immersion, for example, two hollowed Royal Soldiers beating the hell out of giant trees, like if they still followed orders mindlessly. Overall, the game feels slower, more tactical and thoughtful, immersive. and co-op oriented.

SotFS gets 10/10 in this category.

ITEM PLACEMENTS:
The most notable change is Dull Ember being almost in the beginning of the game. Some of chests' contents have changed, some chests were added as well. Most of them contain weapons and shields you'd get later in the game, and some bodies contain weapons that took time to get, but weren't way too powerful (Whip, for example). Out of the most non-spoilerey weapon placement changes: two Broken Straight Swords in the beginning of the game instead of one. I've not seen any new armor placements, but now some sets that were only available in NG+ are now farmable in regular NG pretty early in the game. Go get your hands on your Shadow Sets and enjoy your SL 30 Uchigatana builds, folks.

8/10 for item placements

MULTIPLAYER:
I haven't played the new larger scale PvP yet, but I indeed had some fun with co-op. For some locations it is recommended now (Heide's Tower of Flame, I'm looking at you), and for some reason it's way too much fun. With three (maybe more) summons at the same time, this game really turns into a jolly co-op experience. With more enemies added on stages, four players in one co-op sessions seems to be barely enough. Now to a little bit of PvP I've played. Just once I invaded a guy and his summon at Heide's Tower of Flame, and it feels good. Enemy placement does miracles, and the host won't be able to tank you out while his friend takes care of enemies anymore. Invasions turned from a PvE-quicklyclearthearea-PvP-PvE' experience to constant pressure from both players and enemies
date: no matter how many players are you co-oping with.\n\n9/10
recommended:
a subject to change since I'm yet to see large scale fight clubs and PvP in general

A NEW INVADER:
An NPC invader that invades you in Forest of Fallen Giants with the Blue Flame
hoursPlayed:
Soul Greatsword and Soul Vortex. Pretty much speaks for itself. I want his set.

low SM build/10

SAVES:
They don't transfer. But to me it wasn't even a downside: I usually don't even go on NG+1.

Indiffirent/10

CONCLUSION:
I'll be honest: I own the original DkSII

reviewText:
The unloved little brother? Maybe for some, but it is family, still For me Dark Souls II had the job of filling Dark Souls I's foot steps and from what I heard before playing, it had a very tough standing with me. Some of my pessimistic expectations got confirmed, not all though. In the end, I got stuck with it. And not because there is nothing better to play.

So here are some bullet points about my mental starting point and in opposition my verdict so far.
I try to focus on what gripped me most, that being lore and atmosphere, also the frustration/accomplishment ratio and Online Playing.
Finally I add a tl;dr kind of conclusion.

What I thought I knew about it, before I even owned it:
It is too try hard in being difficult, maybe even plain unfair.
They misinterpreted the source of success, that made DSI the ember that slowly grew into a steady flame, even a bonfire (Firelink Shrine):
You associate it with home and - just like home - might have dreaded the return at first, but when finally entering, all those memories remind you of its livelyness. pull you in, stuff you with heaps of food (not just the sweet but also the healthy, sometimes bitter kind) and finally necessary goodbyes are a pain. So much, that you can't but visit the interwebz and claw for more: lore interpretations, artworks, guides and ideas for your next char, speedruns...  but i digress.
The story.... what story?
Unfaithful Miyazaki's creativity ran off and had an affair with Bloodborne.
This double release thing smells.
Is the Coop/ PvP Sys any good?
After a few hours on tape, here is what I think now:
Yes it tries hard to be difficult. Especially in the first area (Forest) I still get cranky about the invisible column every mob seems to rotate on and hitting me last second, no matter, if they wear a turtle tank outfit weighing a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. But luckily that ceases to be much of a problem later on.
The fact, that you cannot really counter this resulting randomness simply with skill, has also been home to Undead Burg (DSI), so I can't really complain in that department. (Speedrunners said that, not me! So no 'git gud' plz.)
I have to say, in DSII I found myself shouting and spitting: THIS IS JUST UNFAIR! a lot more often than in DSI. Levels can be mean and harder than their bosses, we have read it here. More bonfires do help a bit though. Ergo this point stays on the list for me.

Home? Firelink Shrine is one thing, maybe your parents home, considered you have good childhood memories. Majula is another, maybe your first own flat in a different city.
They are both home, but in different ways.
The return to Demon's Souls hub design makes comparison just as hard. So I limit it to saying, I very much felt at home in Majula as well, and that is an important starting point to falling for the series imho.
This particular feel, maybe because it plays music where there is none otherwise, maybe because of the dusky light with its melancholic vibe or because of those people inhabiting this forgotten spot by the cliffs. It fits.
Would have been awesome, if they made more of a development - or rather degradation - in those NPCs. This would have made the location a perfect paradox, a safe resting place for you, a brutally beautiful harbinger of oblivion and nothingness for the others.

The hub design produced less interwoven levels. Warping made shortcuts unneccessary, I get that. But this little tinge of achievement, when you turned the lever or activated this elevator, I kinda missed that. DLC tried to make a better job at least.

Story or lore wise I do not think they changed much conceptionally. I liked the basic idea of humanity in DSI better and the woven lore seemed a bit more tighter knit, layered and more easily understandable/accessible for a starting point. The sequel's strong point is building up on this lore fundament. But they could have invested more here imho.
Taken for its own lore, I missed a lot up until the ending, which I did not get at first when it played: So thats it? Seriously? But after a visit to vaati a lot suddenly made sense. And the backtracking afterwards - checking, if the videos had a basis - pulled me in and got me into thinking, just as much as DSI had (and no other game before that).
There is history, tragedy, ambivalence in character (friend or foe alike) and questions asked, that I want to seek answers to myself.
BUT I miss NPC quest lines on the scales of the Onion Knight or Solaire. The Pate and Cale thing was a fun idea though.

Creativity in design or mechanic? Mh...Not my area of expertise.
Anyway this is a tough thing, because DSI had no expectations to fill with me, but there was less recycling and less 3v1. DSII: Some bosses felt (sometimes even were) the same. Looking Glass Knight (DemS?) or Old Iron King had some fun ideas. Though frustrating, Fume Knight was boss.

Double release still smells to me, but it got fainter.

Online Playing.
They made a lot differently, most to the better, I think. So start with my
Negatives:
-The Soul Memory system makes it a mean job to try and keep your overall souls count low, in order to avoid the magic Havel with power stancing dragon tooths at some point in late game. Hard thing when you run for the first time and decide to pvp later on.
I need to reserve a ring slot for a soul eating Agape Ring, so not to continue to rise in SM with every PvP or Coop match. Also there's no easy way to recreate the SL120-for-PvP-understanding in DSI. But DSIII wants to change that, I have read.
- Invasion only via consumables, so you continually have to spend souls here as well. While the top ranks of two popular covenants (butterfly-wings-wearing-and-poison-spitting criminals and over-zealous cyber policemen) require you to invade around 500 times succesfully in a row (reds)... Why not just make it esport compatible then, I wonder? With controllable match making or based on rank and not SM.
- No more indictment for cheap players, so duelling honorably is devalued.

The Good things for me:
- No P2P connections means more succesful invasions/coop, lag's still a thing though.
- Power-stancing and many shield piercing weapons add variety to builds.
- No punishment for covenant hopping means more fun for me testing around, although there is less to try out.
- Options to reenable invasions in areas you have already cleared.
- Playing around with rings and items. (Invaded someone in Iron Keep, finally found him waiting on the last of the beams in this chimney kinda thing you drop down from above. Those four? archers standing on top, still in place. The moment before I dropped to the first beam, he activated a seed... it was over fast).
- Over-zealous policemen-to-the-rescue system.
- More Sunlightbros per host!
Conclusion/tl;dr:
Completing the story line and DLCs, I feel a certain emptiness, only finishing a gripping book could trigger. Seeing I even wanted to leave out the second one entirely and just wait for DSIII, I have to admit, this emptiness means something.
Despite its flaws, it has a right to be valued on its own and there, is a top game.

If you have played DSI already, go play II as well.
If not, give it a try. The beginning is hard, but it gets substantially easier, with some infuriating black-outs in between.
If - like me - you love to discover the stories or worlds in games, play DSI first, if not done already. It gives you a basic understanding and makes the world of Drangleic (DSII) much more fascinating.
If you are into gameplay mechanics, play both or better all of them.

To be honest I didn't expect much from this game, and I heard that this was the game were everyone rages and were you need skill. Whilst that is not completely true this game can be quite challenging and requires quite a bit of skill. But you can also cheese the game by playing all the bosses co-op which I don't recommend doing because it will ruin the satisfaction of finally beating a boss after dying a million times (Not literally a million times)

One of the first mistakes I made in Dark Souls II was when I beat the first boss which in my opinion was really easy and after that I actually thought I was invincible all that changed when I walked the wrong way and I met The Pursuer who really isn't the friendliest guy you will encounter in Dark Souls II, so in approximately 5 sec I got punctured by his 400kg sword and I was as dead as a doornail. I thought to myself I must have done something wrong and went back to fight him again this time after getting a few levels higher. But guess what? I got my â™¥â™¥â™¥ handed to me again, and that kept happening for at least 20 times which really broke my spirit and wanted me to quit the game and never play it again, but something had awoken in me and it gave me the urge to continue to try beat this piece of â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. So after some magical hours of dying over and over again I finally managed to stun him with a giant ballista and got two shots in him with it, his health bar so small that you could barely see it. I saw his look of fear whilst he charged his final attack at me which I dodged with finesse whilst at the same time attacking his side with my Fire Longsword. It was over I had slain The Great Pursuer and was left standing with wounds all over my body, but I had done it, after so much time and effort I finally beat it....

After this fight I actually found out that I could have skipped this boss and fought an easier boss but to this day I am still proud that I beat The Pursuer with such a low level character and with so little knowledge as to how to play the game.

To this day this game is one of the top 5 games I have played.

reviewText:
For the Veterans:
Dark Souls II made even better! Loving the new remix of enemy placement and key items. The game flows better now. This is the definitive version of Dark Souls II!

Playing the vanilla, I personally felt that some areas are unfair and unimaginative by throwing tons of tough enemies in one location. This version removes those kind of stuff but at the same made some areas more difficult but not boring.

Graphics isn't as good as DX9 version + Gedosato, but the item and enemies remix, accompanied with lightning upgrade makes this version enjoyable even for me who have spend 100+ hours in the original version.

For the Newcomers:
Starting is tough, but as you level up and learn patterns, you will overcome things you thought impossible.
Be patient, use strategy, be aware of your surroundings.
Some areas with tons of enemies can become much easier if you approach slowly.

Tips:

- Running low on flask and durability near a boss door? Drop your co-op sign and help others win the fight, gain souls, restore flask and durability, and restore humanity, all at the same time while warming up for your own fight.

- For melee build players: dont forget to raise your ADP stat for better rolls.

- If you're overwhelmed, lure enemies so you can take them out one by one. Utilize narrow hallways, doors, walls, stairs, ladders, etc. This game will try its best to kill you so no shame in using all the available options to increase your survival.

reviewText:
I've been playing games from Software since Demon Souls and really enjoyed the original Dark Souls II.

But the Scholar of the  First Sin (SotFS) is what George Lucas did to Star Wars. What was once a game based on exploration and risk taking, has now turned into a game where overpowered monsters stop you from going anywhere but a linear path and the risks have been reduced to the grind of killing enemies over and over.

For instance, Heide Tower and the Heide Knights:

These knights where scattered throughout the world of Dark Souls 2 and you had to defeat them to obtain a weapon or piece of armor (which was no easy feat). Not in SotFS they are all located at Heide Tower and all there loots are now random drops. What makes this enhanced edition" worse is none of the actual mechanics have been tweaked. The hit-boxes are still terribly large leading to moments where you swear you evaded a stabbing blow but it turns out your enemies blade has a magnet or something as you magically get sucked into an animation of you getting stabbed. (this happens way to often).

Also the CLIFFS! You'd figure they would fix how often you magically slip off although both your characters feet are planted firmly on the ground. But that also remains.

In short Dark Souls 2: Scholar of the first sin adds a bunch of crap without actually fixing anything people were complaining about.

I understand that the game is supposed to be hard and unforgiving
date: but it's hard to enjoy that aspect when all the difficulty come from the bad mechanics and not the actual world and enemies."

reviewText:
Writing a review for the best game you've played in your life is a really challenging task, it's even harder than finishing Dark Souls II without dying. I'm not sure what to say, every aspect of this game is better than perfect. Dark Souls II is as good as a video game can possibly be, every person in the world should play this not just hardcore gamers.

Dark Souls II has made me see life through different eyes, it has taught me many valuable lessons. It's much more than just a game you play for fun or passing time. It truly deserves to be remembered, every moment spent playing Dark Souls II should be savored. I'm not exaggerating when I say this, Dark Souls II is a really special and unique game. I just can't find the right words to explain how perfect this game it, YOU MUST PLAY THIS GAME .

Comparing design quality of DLCs with Base Game (DkS2) is like comparing Minesweeper with Battlefield. If Base Game made you grind your teeth, Season Pass will make you tear your hair out. Simply take Level of Difficulty in the base game, then multiply the number by 10 and you'll have an idea of how difficult DLCs are. Season Pass is better than the base game in every single aspect, it's everything Dark Souls II should have been. It almost feels like they cut the best content of their game, only to re-release it as DLC later and make more money!

This is one of the finest RPG titles of this generation, I would highly recommend it to anyone interested in video games

reviewText:
Normally, I'm a big fan of the Souls games, however, one thing I am not a fan of is FROM SOFTWARE's inability to be reasoned with. I was accused of cheating for using a few mods that made the game playable for me. In particular, I was soft-banned for using DS2Fix and x360ce. These two mods do the following:

-DS2Fix: Fix a glitch in the game that causes the durability of your weapons to decrease at twice the normal rate when playing the game at 60 FPS.

-x360ce: Allows you to use directinput gamepads in Dark Souls (in other words, most older gamepads before the XBOX 360 controller).

I have written a request to Bandai Namco to have my ban lifted after admitting that I used these mods (I later bought myself an XBOX 360 controller after finding out about soft-banning), and FROM SOFTWARE told me that since I violated the EULA (even if it was only so that I could play the game the way it was meant to be played), that my soft-ban will not be lifted.

Since a lot of the achievements in the game are a lot more difficult to obtain without any sort of online interactivity, this ruined the game for me in a lot of ways. That is not to say that the achievements and the game are impossible to beat solo, but it will be a much less enjoyable experience as a whole, considering that several bosses are, for the most part, large mobs, as opposed to the much more interesting and creative bosses found in Dark Souls and Demon's Souls respectively.

The game also puts a lot of emphasis on ambushing and surprising you in inconvenient locations just to make sure they get a couple of extra deaths out of you, which in my opinion is just cheap. After being ambushed and dying as a result of said ambush, it becomes pretty easy to figure out what to do in subsequent attempts, but it just seems blatantly unnecessary. The game is not terribly hard, but you will die simply because you're not ready for every single ambush and surprise the game has in store for you.

Another thing I would complain about (but kind of seems moot, considering that I'm soft-banned anyway), is the concept of soul memory. Every single soul you collect is added to a stat that matches you up against opponents (and potential allies) with similar amounts of souls. For novice players, this can be troublesome, considering that a lot of souls that are collected will inevitably go to waste, either through the purchase of items, inefficient leveling, or simply through permanently losing souls. Demon's Souls, Dark Souls and Bloodborne do not utilize this system, and in my opinion, it's better that way.

Lastly, another thing I don't particularly like is the concept that enemies can disappear. Permanently. If you play through a stage enough times, and keep killing the same enemies over and over, they will eventually stay dead, making soul farming more difficult, unless you have plenty of bonfire ascetics onhand. The only problem with using those is the stage that they're used on is raised one more difficulty level and EVERYTHING is reset for that level, which compels you to have to redo the entire stage (it would be foolish not to), and fight a stronger version of the same boss at the end of the level.

Therefore, soft-banning aside, I consider this entry in the Dark Souls series to be the weakest entry in the series. It does a lot of things that makes it ever-so-slightly less enjoyable than other FROM SOFTWARE gems.

All in all, I would recommend this game only if you're a die-hard Souls fan, if you're very careful not to use any sort of mods whatsoever, and if you don't already have all of the original Dark Souls II and its DLC. Remember, ANYTHING other than the what the game originally came with can result in a soft-ban, and you will NEVER get unbanned ever again.

If you want to be safe, you should probably just stick with the PS4 or XBONE versions. FROM SOFTWARE, like a lot of other 3rd party console developers are not particularly good at releasing PC Ports.

TLDR:
-Don't use mods.
-Make sure that you use an xinput gamepad (for example, the XBOX 360 controller).
-Don't purchase if you have DS II with all of its DLC already.
-Not as good as other Souls games.
-Might want to play the PS4 or XBONE versions instead.

Overall:
4/10 - PC Port
7/10 - SOTFS (in general)

reviewText:
Dark souls 2 falls in a weird place for me. I definitely think its worse than Dark Souls 1 but I would still consider it a great game. Keep in mind while reading that I'm mostly into dark souls for the single player experience, and haven't really gotten into any PvP elements at all, those really don't interest me. I will say getting invaded when your trying to head to a boss you've already lost to half a dozen times is really annoying.

Anyway, lets talk about the pros. While the combat is different from Dark Souls 1, and at first I considered it worse, its just different. Rolling works different, weight of your character, weapon swinging and enemy tracking work differently in Dark Souls 2 and after using it for about 25 hours I'd say its still fun, but personally I prefer the combat of the original. I don't really have any complaints or issues with it, but the feel of DS1 was more up my alley. But the combat was definitely fun. Another thing I think this game did well was using different types of healing and other variety of items that felt much more usefull. Lifegems are basically essential to use, especially in the early game. Later on as you obtain more estus, you'll use these items a lot less, which is kind of a shame. I liked the idea that estus wasn't the end all be all of healing. Hopefully dark souls 3 uses more of this element of permanently lost healing items. The enemy desing is impressive and still very good, but not nearly as creative as 1, and I don't really think thats an opinion. I mean one level is just filled with generic spiders, or at least they look like spiders, and its quite boring to look at when you consider what Dark Souls 1 brought to the table. But I'd still consider this a mostly positive point.

Now, the negatives. First of all, a minor one. Why can't I just exit the game without returning to the main menu and having to open it again just to fully quit? Every time I quit it would take me to the main menu. I just want to exit the game! It really annoyed me, but its a minor thing. Another thing, and this is an issue I have with the original as well, give me a pause menu that pauses the game. I realize that they don't want you to be able to spam healing and stuff in a pause menu, but give me a pause that literally does nothing but pause the game. A lot of people, including me, need to be able to pause to do something in real life, or to answer a message, ect. I feel like adding a pause menu that does literally nothing but pause would be a benifit.

Last negative, and the big one. The level design is the most disappointing thing in this entire game. It feels so uninspired. This is probably due to the adding of traveling between bonfires that you get from the beginning instead of later on, making the developers lazy with their level design. But whatever caused it, the levels can basically be described as this. Enter a new area, find the easy to find early bonfire. Find your path to the boss. Find the bonfire thats basically right next to the boss, Kill the boss, get the bonfire after the boss, repeat. Dark souls 1 was much more creative. Sometimes you had one bonfire connecting like 2 or 3 different areas or bosses. And even when you didn't, the level felt more like a world as opposed to a level in a video game. I wish the level design was on the level of dark souls 1, but without it, the game falls below epic.

I will say the game runs well and I had no issues with the port. I think Dark Souls 2 is a smart pick up for those who enjoyed the original, however if you've never experienced a souls game, play the first one before this. Its better, in my opinion.

For most:
Wait For A Sale
For those who loved the original:
Buy At Full Price

reviewText:
GOOD: The Co-op works well enough to earn it a Co-op tag in steam

BAD: The Co-op ranges along with a number of other parts of DS1 have been changed with little to no indication, can be frustrating.

Level design is sub-par to the first game although the eclectic style can be appealing in its own way.

The combat is a HUGE downgrade from DS1 - The game simply becomes one of patience and patterned play, the mobs have infinite stamina and like to use the artificial advantages they've been given. Simply wait for them to finish their 1-5 move combo and then make your move.

Invasion system is now even more stacked towards the invader, now rendering them immune to the npcs/mobs and enabling them to use them against you - Makes for much more boring and annoying invasions.

Luckily the game only starts to take a dive around 2/3rds in rather than half way, but there IS still a noticeable drop-off.

UGLY: Unlike DS1 where mods were more or less mandatory, the developers of this game WILL (even 3 years on with official acknowledgement of their process being HEAVILY flawed) 'softban' you for using certain mods, programs such as DXtory or other video capture software or anything else they decide. The biggest issue with this softban is that there is NO indication or way of knowing you have been softbanned or why, nor is there any appeals process. Good luck playing with your friends without tedious workarounds! That's AFTER you've been secretly banned for doing nothing wrong.
