reviewText:
\[T]/
Dark Souls 2 was 2 easy!
2/10 would not praise again!
...

No, what can I say. The souls series is one of my favorites in gaming. I'll try to approach this review the best I can. Combining both my love for praising of the sun and with a view of the game from a non-die hard fans point of view.

In Dark Souls 2, you are an undead, forever without light, cursed with never being able to die. The game is in third person and looks wonderful as SotFS. Dx11 polishes up and makes the game look pleasing.

The sun in particular.

You're in Drangleic, and within it there are a lot of ways to die. You'll be doing that often, so might as well jump off the first cliff you see so you can get a taste of it now, rather than later.
This game is for the lore lovers and masochists, and at a tipping point sadists. Sometimes both.
You go from Bonfire to Bonfire. Fighting unique and detailed (sometimes) bosses.


Pros:
Artwork and Locations[/h1]
From the items you pick up, to the areas you explore, each one feels and looks unique. From beautiful to horrifying this game will have your eyes wandering, blinded and violated. In the best ways possible. Each place works in favor of itself.

Lore[/h1]
The story is deep. Read every item you find. Every. One. Each contains a bit of lore. Sometimes just some crafting notes, but most of the time, the weapon, item, or armor you find has a place in the world you're playing in. Some are even from the distant past. Long, long ago.. back when Gwyn, Lord of Cinder vanquished the dragons.

Sound and Music[/h1]
Silence is scary. Noises are vibrant and feel nearby. While there is a score, most of the time you'll be hearing nothing. Followed by sounds of..whatever doesn't Praise the Sun. The music you will hear is usually contained within the boss battles you'll be doing. Turn your volume up.

Bosses and Mobs[/h1]
Each boss is different. Each boss has it's own story. Enemies as well. A wide spectrum and ray of bosses await you. From the benevolent to the putrid, every last boss will be a remembered experience. Some you can skip but, I highly recommend you defeat them all.

PvP[/h1]
The souls series uses an invasion and soap stone placement for PvP. Meaning, at any given moment in the game, another player may use a Cracked Red Eye Orb and attempt to invade your world. It works both ways. Another thing you're allowed to do is place a sign down, allowing others to summon you in for what would be hoped a respectable match of fisty cuffs. Sometimes this is not the case. Beware. Always.

Difficulty[/h1]
While difficult at first, if you take the time to learn the curve you will inevitably come to Praise the Sun. You can even fuel your addiction for praising by burning items to increase the surrounding area's difficulty.

Replay Value[/h1]
I got a lovely 64 hours in on DS2. Worth every death. After beating the game you can either clean up the area and do side quests or devote yourself to a covenant or... you can begin you're second (third) journey to Drangleic. Increasing all area's difficulty +1. Hence, often referred as NG+(+)

Rewarding[/h1]
Each death is either a lesson or another key missing off your keyboard. Regardless once you've completed whatever, or whomever you're struggling on there's a sense of accomplishment. One that I haven't really felt as strongly for with any other game. It is painful, but it is rewarding and bittersweet.

Voices[/h1]
You wont ever hear your character speak or say anything aside from their death throes and screams. Aside from that, the voice actors you will hear did a pretty decent job of fitting the characters you'll be encountering throughout the game.

The Sun[/h1]
Self Explanatory
[/list]

Cons:
Camera[/h1]
While the camera will usually be your friend, if you ever get back into a corner or hit a particular angle: You might as well die. Nothing too major to gripe about, still worth a mention.

Sprites[/h1]
If using a bow or zooming in and you spot an enemy a long distance away, you'll notice that sprite like animation. Where the enemies look jittery and almost buggy, as if the fps surrounding them suddenly dropped to 5. This didn't happen often but when it did, it was always an un-immersive eye sore.
[/list]


Conclusion:
DARK SOULSâ„¢ II: Scholar of the First Sin is a highly enjoyed game with a deeply embedded story, rich visuals, stunning displays and divinely disturbing music.
I recommend this game to any and all who are willing to die, over and over. With a sweaty-palmed sense of accomplishment, this game will have you neck deep in souls and sun light.
Either wait for a sale, or drop the money bags for the current price ($50) doesn't matter. You're dead in this world. The only thing that matters is the Sun. Praise it.

Praise the Sun/Sun.
Would Sun again.

reviewText:
It may seem odd that someone who's played more than 200 hours of a game would give it a bad review. The truth is, I kept coming back to Dark Souls II, hoping I'd see something better in it, something that made it worthy of calling itself a sequel to one of the greatest RPGs ever made, but I never did, no matter how desperately I looked.

To make a long story (or rant in this case) short, everything you could possibly want from a Dark Souls game isn't in this. Exciting, strategic combat has been replaced. Every weapon has damn near the same speed, so PvP is entirely about trading hits and PvE is entirely about praying that the enemy you're facing doesn't start it's next combo with it's no-start-up-frames flurry. Interconnected, metroidvania style level design is replaced with straight shots, spreading out like spokes from the starting town. As for the world itself, physically believable locations, all of which could be seen from one another, are replaced with...well, you take an elevator up past a windmill and end up in a volcano.

With Dark Souls 1 already released and Dark Souls 3 weeks away (when this review was written), this isn't the kind of sequel that's going to be looked back on fondly as a standout entry in the series. It definitely stands out, but for all the wrong reasons.

reviewText:
-Graphics were greatly improved. Shaders and illumination have grown extremely in quality, while textures also got an increase in quality but without having much of an impact as the new shaders/illumination have.
-If new to Dark Souls 2, this edition has the same price as a new game (and less than the standard 60 USD mark) and comes with all 3 DLC, which many claim, and I agree, are even better than the base game (not to minimize the quality of the base game).
-New audio touches, many of them add to immersion, while being something small, it adds to the whole experience.
-New enemy placement: there has been many changes regarding enemy placement, in some places there are even more (thus effectively making the GAME HARDER), in others the enemies are in different spots, there are even some new variants of enemy (say, a Hollow Royal Soldier two-handing a Estoc). These changes make the game harder at points, while at the same time help veterans get some feeling of fresh-ness.
-Maximum players online increased from 4 to 6 (3 invaders and 2 Phantoms (helpers) + the Host).
-Better Optimization.
-DLC keys used to access the DLC areas were blended into gameplay, being found as one plays instead of being given right away to the player once he starts playing. This makes the transition and access to the DLCs more natural and intuitive.
-Better AI takes smarter decisions when it comes to combat and pathfinding, this paired with the fact that at many times you will be outnumbered by enemies (and take into account this version adds even more enemies) makes the game effectively harder, but not unfair.

Overall, I consider this version to be better than the original Dark Souls 2, while the graphic improvements may not be that astonishing, the new illumination its beautiful enough to notice, while the textures improvements are more discrete. A recommended buy for newcomers into the series and a must-buy for fans of the Souls games for it has enough of a fresh feel.

Note: the patch that original versions of the game (PC's DirectX 9, PS3 and Xbox 360 editions) doesn't contain all the things this edition has. In fact, the most important change that adds to the feel of being fresh, the new enemy placements, are exclusive to this new version, and let me tell you: they are worth it.

DISCLAIMER: I have 150 hours on the original Dark Souls 2 on PC and about the same on Dark Souls: Prepare To Die Edition, but I have close to 10.000 hours on Dark Souls 1 and around 700 hours on Dark Souls II for PS3 (I moved to PC later).

reviewText:
If you absolutely loved Dark Souls for every aspect of it, do not get this game. You WILL be disappointed and upset.

If you loved Dark Souls because of it's artstyle, do not get this game. When I first walked into the Heide's Tower of Flame area I thought I had started playing a Kirby game or something.

If you loved Dark Souls because it presented a hard but fair and enjoyable challenge, do not get this game. I love Dark Souls 1 because it manages to be a single player game while at the same time presenting a really fun and decent challenge. And it did so with out relying on any cheap or annoying gimmicks. The same cannot be said for this game. It will repeatedly put you against the same dark magic spewing miniboss time and time again. Somebody in the lighting department decided huehue, DARK Souls, let's make certain areas pitch black DARK. Just to make the player use a torch lighting mechanic that adds nothing to the gameplay what so ever. You will repeatedly lose maximum health with each death that cannot be regained without using this game's equivalent of humanity (did I mention that they completely trashed the old humanity system?).

Farming has been nerfed, now if you kill any enemy a certain number of times they will dissapear entirely from the game, only to return if you use and item that raises the area to the next New game level (NG+. NG++, and so on).

On the topic of health and cheap tactics, all healing has been nerfed. The estus flask heals you much slower, and the only alternative you have to it besides miracles, soul gems, heal even slower. Humanity does not exist in this game so don't even consider relying on that. Healing speed is not the only nerf the estus flask has gotten. The Kindling mechanic is gone. You now start with 1 swig in your flask and can have a maximum of 12. The upgrade process only increases it by 1 at a time. Oh, and you still have to upgrade the actual potency of your drink, that hasn't been made any easier to compensate.

The previous point is worsened by the fact that all character animations have been drastically slowed down. Did you love Dark Souls because of how smooth and fluid it's movements and controls were? Then do not buy this game. I swear my character was walking through some kind of syrup. This is somewhat lessened by adding points into the Adaptability stat (Read as, you must waste souls to level and extra stat in order to use your estus flask without moving in slow motion) but even after that the animations and recovery periods from any action are still slow.

I mentioned an Adapability stat. This is not the only new stat that has been added which is nothing more than a piece of a previously present stat. Remember how nice it was that you could boost equipload and stamina at the same time? Not anymore, that has now been split into 2 stats just to force you to spend more souls in leveling. The splitting of stats has actually even forced the pvp meta up 50 or so levels. Hope you like grinding through enemies that stop respawning.

In all, Dark Souls 2 abandons things which made Dark Souls 1 great, trades fair and fun challenges for annoying and cheap ones, messes with mechanics that did not need to be chagned only to leave them worse than they started, and is overall a disappointment after playing through the masterpiece which was Dark Souls 1. Your money is much better spent on the first game, at this point I am certain that I can guarantee you will have more fun with it.

reviewText:
It took me a while to 'get' Dark Souls. Having played a ton of RPGs, I found it difficult to put aside all the actions I had learned from playing them, and then having to start from scratch with a DS game. Once I realised how to play the game differently from all the others there was no stopping me. I had originally started with DS2 (dx9) but had hit the same roadblock. Now, having bought this version I'm ready to step in again, staff in hand and homing soul pew hovering over my sorcerer's head, living (or should I say hollowing) to fight another day.

SotFS in some ways is different to the original what with enemy placements, loot locations etc. The vast majority of the changes are welcome (I'm looking at you No Man's Wharf), and I only have one or two minor grumbles to mention. I'm just hoping there isn't another Sen's Fortress type of area otherwise I might cry a little.

I kind of understand the grumbles about the new version. Having said that I'm a big fan of From Software and happy to throw my money at them. I don't care if I get hate about this. We're all entitled to our own opinions.

In addition to being a fantastic game, here's a FWIW section ....

Good stuff
*Enemy placement. Having played some of the original I still had held its mental model in my head. So of course, I am having to start from scratch which is great. The game is keeping me on my hollowed toes.
*Music. Matoi Sakuraba is amazing. I listen to the DS music a lot when not playing and hearing the music played while fighting a boss is an amazing feeling!
*Environments. Really interesting environments with nooks and crannies to explore, secrets to find, and enemies to run away from!

Minor grumbles but not game breakers
*Coop. I love summoning and being summoned by other players as there's still that sense of jolly cooperation. I would also like the option to have my summon only available to friends too. To have the choice would be good.
*Meaningful NPCs. Dark Souls had the endearing Solaire, whose story (for me at least) was emotional. I feel that DS2 lacks an NPC of this calibre and would love to experience that sense of 'I must help this person!' in the game. That said, I'm only 20+ hours in so maybe there is an NPC who is as endearing as our wonderful Solaire.
*Soul memory. I just really dislike the feature. It makes me mindful of acquiring souls so I don't out-soul my friends if they are offline. Soul level would be a better indication of coop. Yes, I know there's the Agape Ring but I would still prefer the choice.

If you are new to DS2 then I am confident you will love this game. If you want tips, here are some that a DS friend told me that helped.

- Slow and steady. This is my mantra when playing. Entering a new area? Turtle up, and walk forward slow and steady.
- Try all classes. If you're unsure or finding a particular class annoying, play around with other classes until you feel comfortable with the gameplay. It took me a while to realise I love sorcery. I seriously fecking love sorcerers :D
- It's OK to cheese. It's not cheating, it's being strategic. If you played DS, remember that knight in Undead Burgh? He can't climb ladders. Try luring it out .... :)
- Leave/rate messages. Drangleic is a harsh and unforgiving world. Leave helpful and/or funny messages for your fellow hollows to help them on their way (ambush right, don't give up!). Also rating other players' messages will restore some of their health. You never know they might be fighting a boss when you are rating. Plus it's all in the same spirit as jolly cooperation and Solaire would be proud of you.

Buy the game and I'm sure you won't be disappointed. Remember you're not the only one going through the pain and torture :)

My summon name - Hala Cookie or Hala Creamcakes. Give me a hearty wave if we meet.

Praise the sun!

Hala xxx

reviewText: i haven't recommended this game before? shameful. it's my favorite game.  i love it. there's nothing else like it and no proper way to describe it. the dark souls franchise is my favorite of all my years of gaming, so anything i have to say on the subject is going to be heavily biased.\ndespite that, i truly think you should try this game. whether you've played dark souls or demon souls or even standard dark souls 2, this is by far the best of them all. bringing back the dual weilding for dark souls 2 was a smart idea and the level design changes alone are worth the money. not to mention dark souls has the best online community out there. (again, i am biased, but i stand by it.) very few RPGs have been able to effectively blend the single and multiplayer experience in the way the dark souls series has. you can play for hours by yourself and forget you're online and then stumble into the wrong area at the wrong time and get invaded by someone out of nowhere. the game of cat and mouse and the combat between a real life oppenent in this game is unmatched by any other out there. every kill and death online has meaning-was earned. hard fought. the fights are tense and i love it. the iron keep bridge fight clubs are a huge attraction for me. levelling up your character by testing your skills against other players in a 1 on 1 duel-it's such a blast. and i haven't even really mentioned the enemies. scholar of the first sin is filled with tons of nasty enemies that will punish you for every mistake you make. the bosses even more so. it's another thing i love about the dark souls games. it's that feeling of hitting an obstacle that seems insurmountable until you step back and looks at it, study it, and then finally, conquer it. the dark souls game, and this one especially, capture that feeling in a way no other game has. the feelings of accomplishment are always that much more meaningful when they're preceeded by tons of feelings of failure and frustration at one's own mistakes. i especially enjoyed learning each enemy's moves and attacks and learning what weapon/spell/tactic it would take to defeat them. skill has always been sufficiently rewarded in the dark souls games. and the more of it you have and the better you are at the combat mechanics, the more you are rewarded. dark souls 2: scholar of the first sin is my favorite game...i just wish i could do more than recommend it.

reviewText:
I love dark souls 1 it was much fun to play through the game for the first time and i have to say that i love dark souls 2 just as much mainly because the combat was more refined, polished and fluid.
It wasn't as difficult as the original mainly because i had much more experience with the series and the areas in the game were less frustrating then the original or maybe the developers just made the game easier then the original on purpose i can't really tell. Another big bonus for dark souls 2 is the steady 60fps throughout the whole game, the game just felt soo much more better then the original where it had a 30fps cap and would drop to 15 fps in areas like blightown.
The level design is not as memorable as the original. You remember areas in the original like Anor Londo, Sens Fortress, Ash lake, The painted world etc. The areas in dark souls 2 are not as memorable or interesting. There are a few exceptions of course like Majula which is just beautiful and a much better main hub then firelink shrine. The world of dark souls 2 is not as connected as the original it just has branching paths from majula where in dark souls 1 every area of the game is interconnceted which each other and all link back to the main hub firelink shrine.
The pvp is alot better then the original because not everyone is trying to backstab you every fight and it overall just feels more better making it more fun. It took me 38 hours to beat dark souls 1 and it took me the same amount of time to beat dark souls 2 which was a funny coincidence. The crown trilogy dlc also adds more hours of fun and shows off some great level design and locations. I have to mention that beating the ancient dragon was one of the most satisfying things ever in a game.
9/10 (Amazing)

reviewText:
BUY THIS ONE AND NOT THE ORIGINAL DS2

Completed DS2 at the time making this review (Not NG+)

Dark Souls 2: Scholar of the First Sin is basically a remake of the original DS2 content.
This enhanced edition comes with many great features, this game is also the same price as the original.

Changes:

-SOTFS comes will all the DLC's of the original Version, so basically you get the full package in one.
-DX9 vs DX11, DirectX9 has poor lighting and Anti-Aliasing. It was a shame that the original DarkSouls 2 came out with DX9 and didn't decide to update it to DX11. DX11 offers sharp and crisp visuals, making the game more atmospheric and gives the game a better re-play value.
-Bugs, YES BUGS! most of the bugs have been fixed, there's no wall-clipping, it's basically a super polished version of the original.
-64bit, Finally this version actually supports 64bit! - **** YEAH!.
-60FPS, that's right, most of PC Gamer's wet dreams for this game has become true! Making rolling, and monsters polished!.
-Monsters actually have a 'brain' as they're been polished, some have new attack styles, some are just more fluent.

The changes made the game harder, I still cry when trying to defeat that ******** King's pet. Damn the DLC's are hard! Goodluck!

reviewText:
Alright, 10 hours in.

Firstly, people have been saying that the Graphical upgrade is barely noticable. By and large, they are correct - the game still looks like DS2. Models are slightly crisper, a few improved textures here and there, but NOT worth the Â£20.00 upgrade for the Graphics upgrade alone. The main improvement is in the Lighting department - especially under Torchlight conditions, for example in the Gutter, wherein the light is smoother, shadows are better, the whole thing stutters a lot less - it's fairly awesome in comparison.

Gameplay wise, it's DS2 with all the DLCs and some expanded Flavour texts. However, the developers have also shifted enemy placements, added a few new enemies and many many more NPC Phantoms, Shades and Invaders. Combine this with the new maximum of 6 players (intended for 3v3) and many 'fun' multiplayer events can happen (From Software, whichever developer decided to add the Valley Children invaders in the Black Gulch, there is a spot in hell reserved just for you. I've seen 2 players + 2 AI wiped by 2 of those guys).

However, it all comes down to the simple fact that I was going to buy the DLCs anyway, and this version saved me a couple of Pounds and gave me a couple of boosts to boot! Excellent Value for someone in my position.


TL;DR
-I own DS2, but none of the DLCs
--Worth it if you enjoyed DS2 and/or want to play all the DLCs.

-I own DS2 and some/all of the DLCs
--Probably/Definitely not worth the cost, unless you're really into the Multiplayer and want some 3v3 action.

-I do not own DS2
--You should do. Buy this, it's excellent value for the full content.

All in all, gotten me back into DS again.

reviewText:
To be honest this game is hard to recommend. I still give it a thumbs up, because it does do it's damn hardest to capture the spirit of Dark Souls...just the wrong spirit.

What made Dark Souls great was NOT IT'S DIFFICULTY. It was the way that difficulty communicated the world to you. It build a cohesive, narratively dense environment that communicated its history through the brutal, unrelenting, uncompromising trials you face. Its goal was to build EMPATHY in the player, for the characters and monsters of the world. You intuitively understood that the reason the bosses were so powerful is because they, in turn, had to survive in the same grim reality you do. Dark Souls wanted you to take its world seriously.

Dark Souls II, on the other hand, feels more like fan fiction. The land is thematically disjointed. The characters are mostly perfunctory echoes of the original game. Mechanically, the game does some things different but not in any way that enriches the experience- some design descisions seem to have been made solely to throw off series veterans. Some enemies seemed to have been made just to frustrate, with unpredictable attacks and animations that seem to hit long before you even see them coming.

It's not awful by any means. There some absolutely amazing environmental settings and there are quite a few characters that look more briliant than anything in the entire series. It just feels like a lot of independently good ideas that are held together by duct-tape rather than a unifying theme. The more I play it, the more it feels like this game misses the point.

If you played Dark Souls for the sheer challenge and deep exploration, this game is more of that- in some ways even better.

But if you loved Dark Souls for how it made you FEEL about your own life, this game is severely lacking.

reviewText:
While not as remarkable as Dark Souls, Dark Souls 2 is still a good timesink!

This game seems slightly easier than the previous one and the world isn't as memorable. The main reason for this is that you get access to fast travel right from the start. A lot of the areas are more linear and since you can freely warp between safe zones you'll ignore most of the areas once you've travelled through them once. They lack the reasonable connectivity of the previous game too. That's not to say that there aren't any nice looking areas in this game, it's just you end up spending less time travelling through them and the immersion takes a hit. I enjoyed planning for long trips in DS1 and as a result I probably know Undead Burg better than my actual neighbourhood! (If you hated the constant back and forth in DS1, then this isn't a complaint for you!)

Combat- and techwise this game is an improvement from Dark Souls, everything seems to flow and work better and there's probably even more options for building and gearing your character. Multiplayer is active as hell (even on higher levels I kept getting invaded all the time, human or hollow) and connectivity issues seem non-existent, even with the region lock off. Some in-game systems have been changed for the better and some complications have been streamlined, like now you can swap freely between covenants without penalties, or helping others in co-op heals away your cursed" healthbar and makes you human again. You'll probably still need to consult a wiki to figure some things out or find out how many secrets you've missed.

There's a story that probably makes sense only when you connect all the dots

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I have put over 1k hours in Dark Souls 2, so I'll be looking at this from the perspective of someone who's experienced with the base game.

Dark Souls 2: Scholar of the First Sin is a 'remastering' of the game already released. There's new item locations, new enemy placement, and overall fixes to things that were an issue in the base game. Of course, the game does look nicer: DX11 over DX9, lighting effects are much more apparent and prettier, and a lot of the areas just look...better.

For those who have played the base game, expect some tricky encounters that may play on what you know, and do things that will surprise you. A lot of the encounters require more thought than before, and feel more entertaining to go through. However, some of the new encounters are overdone: There's a miniboss that you can fight three times in under ten minutes in one area. Some areas just increased the number of enemies there, and did nothing to really change the encounter, just threw more at you. For the most part, though, I was happy with how some fights and placements were mixed up.

The new item locations encourage different kinds of weapon use much earlier: Things such as the lance class weapons can be acquired way earlier, so you can experiment with them as you're leveling, instead of waiting until near end game to even find one.

Upgrade materials are also drastically more common: Instead of being forced to stick with one weapon throughout most of the game, you can now upgrade multiple weapons at once much easier, and experiment. This is a very welcome change, as, again, more weapons are available sooner than before.

Netplay is also much more interesting. You can now have one extra summon, and you can also have multiple red/grey phantoms attacking you at once. This can cause some really hectic and enjoyable multiplayer experiences. More importantly, however, Scholar had fun with the NPC summons. There's a lot more gimmick-y builds that you can summon to help, and a lot of them are very good at what they do! They're a lot more fun than the quest NPCs, that's for certain.

Things I didn't like about Scholar: Boss AI is mostly unchanged: All the tricks I used in the base game still work just as well here, including AI loops. DLC areas (These are built into Scholar, by the way: You just have to find the keys!) are unchanged, and as mentioned, some of the encounters are a bit much in the wrong ways.

Overall, if you are new to Dark Souls 2 and want to experience the game fresh? I highly recommend Scholar. It enhances a lot of the things from the base game, and while it still has issues, remains my favorite game in the Souls series. If you've already played the hell out of DkS2 and it's DLCs? Maybe wait for a sale, but the game changes enough so that you'll still be interested in plowing through it once more.

reviewText:
I've already reviewed Dark Souls II - the summary being that I didn't recommend it, but mostly because I think it's a very unpredictable thing if someone will get a kick out of frustration and failure. Not a bad game, just not something that everyone's going to like. A lore that's only hinted at in bits and some unfortunate graphics in spots only heighten this uncertainty.

However, SotFS edition I'm just going to not recommend at all.

It doesn't do much with 64-bits? Possibly the wider register will help with some mid-powered systems but for some reason the minimum requirements have jumped up a bit. Strange since the 'updated graphics' are virtually non-existent. There are plenty of comparison shots online to browse and maybe for some people it will be compelling but it seems to be little more than a different graphical filter. By no means did they overhaul their textures, so don't expect your graphics card to be getting more of a workout.

The game balance has been ruined in favour of expanded multiplayer. This is probably a criticism that not everyone is going to agree with - I'm sure there are plenty who think it's still not hard enough. Or there are those whose sole retort will be 'get good', and bravo on their wit. But, where the difficulty had previously felt correct for the experience, there are now many places that feel like you're being strong-armed into summoning others. This new scaling has resulted in single player feeling untenable in places and, should you get 5 or 6 people together, pretty much make any encounter a joke.

Finally, they've altered the location of enemies. This might be a somewhat petty complaint but they didn't just move enemy type A from location X to Z. They didn't just give A a couple of friends. They replaced enemy A with enemy E which, as far as I can tell, shouldn't be there according to the bits of lore I've seen. Sure, maybe I missed something. Maybe they just wander freely and have a movie night or something, but it feels like they're just ignoring what they want in the name of changing it up a little to justify a price tag that shouldn't have been set so high.

reviewText:
So what has changed in this version?

Enemy placement and item placement. Some NPC locations have also changed. These changes are enough to surprise an experienced DS2 (vanilla) player. There are new NPC invaders and new NPC summons. New NPC summons are greatly improved and are more humanlike now. They even do gestures. Also there's a new final boss who is worthy of being a final boss. Some graphical improvements, mainly lighting effects. Dark areas actually require a torch to navigate now. Also all the DLC content has been integrated into the core game.

So is this worth buying?

If you haven't played Dark Souls 2 before, absolutely worth it.
If you have played Dark Souls 2 but not the DLC content, absolutely worth it.
If you have played Dark Souls 2 and the DLC content, consider the changes and decide yourself.

Overall a superb game and one that is worthy of the Dark Souls name.

P.S:- Just make sure that your graphics card support DirectX 11 before buying this game.

reviewText:
From what I see, most of the negative reviews come from people who previously purchased Dark Souls 2 standalone plus the DLC and bought this in addition. They sey that it isn't worth the money because they are just paying for better graphics.

Well let me tell you, if you don't currently own Dark Souls 2, then definately buy Scholar Of The First Sin. It is just a GOTY edition pretty much, it gives you all the DLC plus an extra place to explore, improved graphics and a smoother gameplay.

Don't let the negative reviews hinder your choice, it is just people complaining that they paid Â£30 for improved graphics. The game itself is awesome, fluent and runs incrediably smoothly.

I don't usually write reviews, but it annoys me to see that people are rating this game negative when the game itself its completely fine. They are just complaining that they had wasted money.

Gameplay; 10/10 - The fighting is nice and the boss' are unique.

Story; 7/10 - I dont really understand much of the story, it isnt much explained, however I havn't yet completed the story so this rating isn't permanent.

Replayability; - NA/10 - Like I said I havn't completed the game yet however I feel like the game would be easily replayable because there are many different classes to explore with.

Graphics; 9/10 - Major improvement from the first Dark Souls, the game in general just looks beautiful.

Optimisation; 10/10 - I can run the game on Max settings at 60 fps (which is a change from the first Dark Souls where there was a 30 fps cap) without any lag spikes. I've seen people be able to play at 60 fps with GPU's and CPU's worse than what is required, so performance shouldn't be an issue unless you are trying to run on a toaster.

Overall Rating ; 9/10 Such a worthy purchase, im 19 hours in and I dont even think i'm remotely close to reaching the end.

reviewText:
Alright, hear me out with this. I can understand the mentality behind not wanting to get it again if you already have the game, which is fair. However, the allure this has in comparison to non SOTFS is this: Content.

Step back and ignore the whole DX11 fiasco and focus on the content of DS2 and DS2:SOTFS.

If you're knew to purchasing DS2, this is the edition to go for. Comes packaged with all DLC. Clean. No mess.

Already have DS2? Then I'll elaborate.
SOTFS adds a lot to the baseline experience. Enemy placements where they make sense. (Seriously, Heide's tower of flame with no Heide knights BEFORE SOTFS? Fromsoft pls. Now the place actually has them.) As Bracketed, one such example will be the heide knight placement changes and how they act. Ignoring the cathedral of blue path, going along the normal path to the dragonrider has multiple heide knights giving not a care in the world about you prattling on about your daily business - Until you kill the dragonrider. After killing the big red man, they stand to roam about, seeking to screw your merry day up with multiple perforating stab wounds. Oh, there's also now a guardian dragon by the bridge to blue cathedral. Guardian. Dragon. Low levels. Hellkite Drake anyone?

Graphics: personally, I can't tell much of a difference between the graphics of DS2 and DS2:SOTFS. I'm much more focused on not, say, loosing various organs to the NPC's or invaders. I like my innards where they are. Inside. I digress, the lighting changes are much more immersive than DS2. Gets dark: Truly dark, when entering basement areas or areas with little light reaching it in the first place. Small, minor changes can make the experience much more fluid.

Online: I haven't had ANY trouble online. Faster matchmaking. More phantoms. More chaos. Lack of blue-bro PvP sadly. I like being blue. Everything I see is blue.

Overall rating? Probably an 8/10.

reviewText:
Dark Souls II is an epic fantasy rpg set in an undead medieval world. To clarify, Scholar of the First Sin is the remastered version of the original game. It comes with all the DLC bundled, as well as having some minor changes to the game itself. This review will first cover the game itself, and then the enhancements added by Scholar of the First Sin.

As a disclaimer I am a huge Dark Souls fan; I had already played Dark Souls I & II on Xbox 360 before playing this.

MAIN GAME:
This is a fantastic game. It is easily one of my favorite games of all time. Artistically, it differs slightly from the first Dark Souls; the first game is more gritty and realistic, this one is more fantastical and surreal. But both games are a masterpiece in their own right. The core gameplay elements are pretty much the same as the first Dark Souls, so returning players will feel at home.

Pros:
+Epic plot that subtly builds as the game progresses. While this game is not very story based" in the most traditional sense (cutscenes
recommended: etc.) it has an overwhelming amount of story and lore hidden away in the game. People who liked Lord of the Rings for all the excess lore that the series had hidden away will love Dark Souls.\n+Excellent characters. This game is mostly a lonely game where the main character travels and fights without speaking to anyone. But whenever you meet an npc they are almost always an interesting character. Like in Dark Souls I
hoursPlayed: the player will slowly understand more of the story as they reach new places and meet npcs.\n+Artistically beautiful game. This game takes advantage of atmosphere to make important moments in the story leave a greater impression on the player. The setting always feels new and unique in different areas. The most important plot moments are always highlighted by a setting desgined to create a specific look and feel. This game tells a story with few words
voteText: and that is its most impressive quality.\n+Addictive gameplay. I found Dark Souls II to be even more addicting than Dark Souls I. And I was pretty addicted to Dark Souls I. The gameplay follows a simple system where the player can either block with a shield or dodge by rolling. Doing either of these actions or pressing the attack button consumes stamina. This simple system makes for unexpectedly deep battles. Positioning the character in relation to the enemy is crucial
helpfulPercent: because the player has to plan where the best spot is to deal with different attacks.\n+Loads of hidden weapons and armor
votesHelpful: with reinforcements and elemental infusions available.\n+The silly ragdoll physics in the first Dark Souls where dead bodies stick to you and can be kicked around like a soccer ball have been removed.\n+Even more extensive multiplayer than the first game. Lots of covenants available. Summoning and invasions galore. You can also play the game cooperatively or alone
votesTotal: like in the first game.\n+Extreme amount of replayability. I have never played any game series with as high replayability as Dark Souls (both I & II). There are secret areas to explore. There are loads of hidden weapons/armor sets. There are hidden

reviewText:
The Dark Souls series is not for the faint of heart, it's very punishing but at the same time, one of the most rewarding games if you manage to stick to it. People who are impatient will likely not finish this game even on first playthrough.
After beating this game so many times with different style-combinations in NG, I think NG+ and beyond is where the challenge actually is.

One of the best games of this generation. Amazing lore, gameplay, sound fx, and boss fights.

Dark Souls 2 is one of those games that you just keep wanting more of and ruins most of the other games you play because of how much they pale in comparison. After beating DS2, first time through, the only game I wanted to play was SOTFS because all the other games I've had felt like crap.

Many fans of the first game doesn't like this game because of the more linear routes but I think they did that to bring the game to more mainstream audiences. It's not a terrible thing in my opinion, most of my casual friends playing this game still got stuck and lost (they probably would've gave up if it were DS1 with how the map works and no TP till later on) I've played through the first game and I think it's actually much easier than SOTFS. Some areas were plain annoying, rather than challenging (looking at you, blighttown).

In terms of combat, pvp, bosses, itemization, graphics and upgrade system, this is a step up from the previous game. I have to admit the original DS2 on release was pretty terrible in comparison to this final copy done in the form of SOTFS. SOTFS brought many needed balancing changes and upped the difficulty tenfold which made it a lot more fun actually. The DLC areas are also amazingly done and brought back some of that level design from Dark Souls 1. Many people who criticize this game never played SOTFS + DLC areas. I suggest that they do that before giving a proper opinion.

10/10 GOTY. Here's hoping for the best in DSIII!


*forgot to add, a controller is recommended but not a must

reviewText:
A fantastic Action RPG that is better than its predecessor in most ways.  Those new to the Souls (Demon's, Dark) games, this is my recommended to start with.  The Scholar of the First Sin version brought some new twists due to new enemy placement, which was enjoyable after having beaten the vanilla version several times.

The Souls games are the best there is to offer for Action RPGs between the skillful combat, leveling system, puzzle and challenge, interesting twist on multiplayer, interesting and epic world, and the quality and quantity of content.  While not to say other games aren't good, they can certainly pale in comparison--I already felt the Elder Scrolls lost something after Morrowind, so except for the excellent SureAI conversions (Nehrim, Enderal), I have even less desire to go play such.

I highly recommend this game and the other Souls (no, no need to play them in order, and yes, I think they have successively gotten better but are all excellent).

reviewText:
The design chances pertaining to enemy and item/key placement are a major gamechanger, things make more sense now both thematically and design-wise. Things like ledges and vertical space are better used in the form of sniper enemies and mages you can take out to make an encounter easier beforehand, enemy types are also utilized better, better use of level design like that enhances the game and makes it feel like Miyazaki Souls, even though it isn't.
The world space is the same, but this remake utilizes it MUCH better. Veterans of the original one I think will be amazed at how the changes affect the game for the better, and how easier it is to make varied builds with important items being accessible earlier (Dull Ember comes to mind, as well as some weapons like the Greatsword).

The way they integrate DLC into the world also makes it feel like it was always there from the start, not addons, which is great.

The lighting is much better and more natural looking now, the strong orange glow is gone from daytime areas replaced with a more natural looking sunlight look, and dark areas have more contrast to them (the torch is needed in some areas if it's your first time exploring it, too bad we veterans already know their layout so we don't get this benefit).

There are also multiplayer improvements, with 6 player active multiplayer and pools of blood" packing multiple bloodstain deaths into one (very amusing if you check the ones near pits).

Overall
date: this is the DS2 that should have been in the first place. Are you willing to put the upgrade asking price to experience what you should have gotten in the first place? You decide

reviewText:
It's a decent, robust dungeon crawler with lots of equipment, spells, 4 schools of magic, and lots of content, but I can't help but feel disappointed by it, because it simply can't live up to the wonderful experience that was Dark Souls I, thanks to its poor, often overly linear level design, poorly thought-out world (both in terms of level placement, and the lore of the world), and idiotic, polarising mechanics changes that happened for no reason.

In terms of how it stacks up against the original Dark Souls II, it's slightly better. Scholar of The First Sin, however, has been criticised too much for the shady business practices behind it, and too unfairly lauded much more than it deserved, when it came to its design changes; and people ignore glaring design flaws that would be criticised to no end in other games. For example, the Pursuer, an early boss in the game, is supposed to pursue the undead, so Scholar of the First Sin opts to place him all about the world. An interesting idea, yeah, but every single Pursuer encounter has the exact same moveset, exact same weapon, and exact same basic arena (that being a large circular or rectangular plane). Other changes, too, like the Heide Knights (an obviously unfair enemy; being able to break out of your combos and instantly lash out for huge damage, encouraging the player to game the system with ranged tactics) appearing in Heide, or the Fragrant Branch of Yore system being much more heavily engrained result in some even more utterly unforgiveable situations; it is literally possible to get stuck in the Lost Bastille, and forced to kill yourself, if you use a certain Fragrant Branch. Needless to say, the level design may visit some interesting locales and vistas, but the actual layout of the levels themselves, and the movement engine, too, is on-par with amateur projects in Unity, even if it is a slight improvement over vanilla DS2.

Speaking of amateur projects, Dark Souls II's enemies and bosses are also utterly uninspired and game-y. The Old Iron King is a giant, Diablo-like torso, which you fight in a wasteland of lava, and it shoots fire lasers out of its hand. Dark Souls even tackled a similar concept with one of its bosses, but it was executed far better, given a genuinely tragic and sad backstory, and some interesting behaviours, and strangely enough, the Old Iron King is just as bad, gameplay-wise, as its Dark Souls I counterpart. There are also plenty of polarising mechanical changes. Combat in Dark Souls II may seem faster to inexperienced players, but in reality, pretty much every player action in combat has been artificially slowed down; you now chug estus at a leisurely, insanely slow rate, regenerate stamina at a I've never done cardio in my life" rate

reviewText:
I admit, it wasn't really cool when From Software decided to charge people $60 for a game that already existed, except they changed things around / the improved edition add on. However for those who already owned Dark Souls 2, got a huge discount and only had to pay $19.99 instead to upgrade their game.

I'm just pointing that out before giving this game the actual review, because although I am a huge fanboy of Dark Souls, I won't be biased and ignore the bullcrap stunt From Software pulled. With that said, let's begin shall we?

Difference between Dark Souls II and Scholar of the First Sin
I feel it's highly important to point out what the differences are. After playing a good 120+ hours on this game, trying out different builds and getting 100% achievements for this version... it's safe to say I know the major differences are, between the first version and this one.

Enemy placement is the biggest one that comes to mind. A huge portion if not every enemy type in the game is placed at different locations, so despite the locations / zones haven't changed, the enemy locations have dramatically changed. For the most part, this is a positive thing because some rough areas are now easier in this area. At the same time, one or two zones have became unfair or highly annoying to fight through but otherwise it's for the best.

Story / characters haven't changed all that much. You'll run into them in different areas now, and their AI have improved so you'll not see Lucatiel fall to her death anymore (or as often now). Sad to see From Software didn't try improving the story or plot, let alone the elements that makes Dark Souls II insuperiror to the first Dark Souls game.

When you purchase this version, you get all the DLCs for Dark Souls II with it in a bundle. But rather than being given the keys right off the bat- you have to explore the world and find them. Two of them are hard to find, while one you pick up along the way without trying. I must advise, if you do the DLCs ... wait till you've beaten the game first. But don't go into NG+ either because it'll make the DLCs all the harder unless you want a bigger challenge.

When you enter NG+ ... more red phantoms to fight and this 'Forlorn' invader will likely invade you at random. No matter how many times you've beaten him, he has the chance of invading you at some point again in your travels. While it is annoying, you do get certain NPC loot which wasn't there in Dark Souls II's first version. Speaking of invasions, you are likely to have more co-op signs / invasions occur because the servers have improved vastly. I hardly have trouble finding online players because the connection is solid.

Improved graphics, which isn't saying much. While it does look better than the first version of Dark Souls II ... it isn't breath taking in the leap. I dare say I didn't really notice until certain areas lit up the place. Apart from the lightning and details standing out more, graphics didn't get that much of an upgrade.

Secret Final Boss at the end after meeting certain requirements. But this is a fail of a boss, not fun nor challenging. Heck this optional boss doesn't offer you souls nor an item drop. It's to basically unlock a 2nd ending, which still sucks on par with the first ending (did I mention the endings to this game blow?)

Hidetaka Miyazaki did not take part in this game, just as he wasn't involved with Dark Souls II. This is also why people feel the game's story / plot / characters aren't as immersive as Dark Soul's cast.

Tweaks to the spells, weapons, cost of items, improved item descriptions, range of co-op soul memory works, and more are all present. They're minor in the end so it isn't going to make me give it more points since it's kind of expected for a company to update their game in favor of the players.
Looking into the game itself, the gameplay is solid, replayability has always been a strong point in the Dark Souls series, bosses are fun (too many are humanoids though, and a few are not memorable in the slightest), characters / stories are weak, PvP is really addicting to take part in, mechanics have dramatically improved in comparison with the first Dark Souls game, and the DLCs are entirely worth completing for they offer a lot of rich content.

Is Scholar of the First Sin Worth It?
For $60 ...? No, i'd rather stick with the first Dark Souls II game. While this is better than the first version, I don't believe it's worth buying it as another game entirely. Is it worth getting for $20 if you already own Dark Souls II? Yes, I agree that is a legit price. Deep inside, I want this to be a free upgrade to those who bought their game, but From Software decided their biggest patch was worth charging people money.

Dark Souls 2: SotFS as a GAME gets a 8 / 10 score from me, because the game as a whole is freaken great.

SotFS Edition gets a 5 / 10 ... not enough content added to Dark Souls 2 to consider it a whole new game. In fact i'd go for a 4 out of 10 if it wasn't for the enemy placement and tweaks being such a huge impact to the experience. I again feel it's worth it, ONLY if you already own Dark Souls 2. Otherwise don't bother unless you really want a Dark Souls 2 game but at this point, i'd wait for Dark Souls III to come out this April 16th.

Pros:
- Graphics are much improved.

reviewText:
From an avid (but not crazy) player of Dark Souls 2;
Note that this is only for the first portion (forest and tower) of the game.

The new spawns look like they were placed by a child. If this is representative of the rest of the game then I'm disappointed I purchased this, even though I didn't have the DLC before.

Turtle knights are placed in front of doorways they can't fit through.
Heide Knights all over the Tower of Flame have monstrously screwed-up pathing (after you kill dragon rider and they all go hostile.) They run all over the place like idiot robots, which was perfectly fine in the nicely constructed original spawns but doesn't work at all there. Half the time they just fall off a ledge.

I think the fact that you can still path-glitch the dragon rider is worth a mention too. I like free souls but, seriously?

Crowds of fodder-soldiers have a tendency to simply bum-rush you rather than wait for opportune moments, like they did when they were intelligently placed in the original...

And this is just an hour or so into the game... not even, likely. I don't mind that I can't really farm tower because i bugged the dragonrider and now Heide knights are going nuts (as deprived facing a bunch of those plus big guys at the same time in those little areas is a bit much for me at the moment.) But getting to the last giant is WAY easier. Did they lower the HP of turtle knights? My unupgraded mace, which I barely have the STR for, takes them in three hits! What's the point of placing them everywhere if they're going to be more fodder?!

The original game had mostly intelligent placement that really kept you on edge even on the third playthrough. This... looks like some dude got really excited with all the big armored guys and couldn't stop placing them in areas he thought would really disappoint players.

Good job.

*Review Update 12-29-15
Having now gone through the entire game, plus some of the Sunken King DLC, I can say that the dev update to positioning is absolutely horrible.

Some areas are easier, some are ridiculously harder (and I mean ridiculous - I don't mind hard, but unfair is too far.)
Some notable stupid placements (like they didn't test them at all) are the desert sorceress on the balcony in harvest valley, shooting fireballs down at you without any way to hit back until you make it up there. Manikens also in harvest valley are just everywhere, and you can't see them until they stab you in the back because they're out of sight on top of rafters.
Dark Souls is supposed to be about intelligently taking in your surroundings and training yourself to notice where enemies are. That's why the maniken jumps down the ladder when you get close, so you have time to react! The new maniken placements don't give you any time to react. They're like cheap horror-film shock value.

That's only a few of many. The increased threat makes small areas like the Iron Keep laughable. Where enemies once forced you to go in cautiously and engage them in close quarters, now they all just sprint towards you from half the map away which allows you to take them easily one by one whereever you choose.

And there are just mobs of enemies which makes dexterous, intelligent, play harder while the big sword and board nub wielders are rewarded for their flailing.

All in all, if you don't have the DLC then maybe this is, or was, a good purchase. Of course at this point you're probably better off waiting for DS3, which has the original developer back on board.
But if you have the DLC then just stick with the original. There's no reason to put yourself through some poorly designed areas when you have good ones already.

To celebrate victoryâ€¦ And to show his love, his gratitude to his Queenâ€¦ The Queenâ€¦Brought peaceâ€¦ to this land, and to her King. A peace so deepâ€¦it was likeâ€¦ The Darkâ€¦ Is thisâ€¦some sort of a dream? â€¦â€¦ Where am I? What has happened to our castleâ€¦ Who are youâ€¦'' -Chancellor Wellager\n\nThe most prominent feature of the Souls game is how they narrate their story. They make you scrape off the surface to find crumbles of the gloomy past... Of the gloomy kings and kingdoms. Souls games are only known with their difficulty, but there is more to it than that. It's its enviromental story telling, item descriptions, obfuscating, yet tactfully put level design. Although this game is directed by Tomohiro Shibuya and Yui Tanimura, and not Hidetaka Miyazaki himself, the legendary director behind Demon's Souls and Dark Souls, it's still quite something, and almost (!) as striking.

reviewText:
I was pretty late to play DS1. But after I did, I would say it is one of my favourite games of all times. I was hoping I'd get the same (or better) experience with DS2, however this was not the case. Let me explain my reasons and go from least to most important:

1. The graphical improvements are really small. DS1 with DSFix looks almost as good as DS2. And while the game never dropped below 60FPS (which is nice of course), they accomplished this with some very noticable tricks, like reducing animation quality of enemies which are far away.

2. The online components of the game have been improved, which is good. However now you can be invaded even when you're hollow. I find this really annoying. I want to see the player messages and bloodstains, which can sometimes help you if you're lost, without beeing invaded every minute in certain places, by peoply who are farming new players.

3. The changes to the health system and weapon durabilty are really frustrating. Everytime you die you're health bar decreases. This can only be reverted if you use a human effigy, of which you have only a limited amount unlike in DS1. Your weapons durabilty goes down a lot faster, and while the durabilty resets at bonfires, it's really annoying, especially when you're trying to explore a new area.

4. The combat is in my opinion feels clunkier. The game feels less responsive than DS1 and I can't really pinpoint why exactly. In DS1 it was possible to go through the game with a low level character if you knew what you were doing. But in DS2 even at Level 120 I didn't really feel that strong. Maybe I leveled the wrong stats. I don't know...

5. DS1 had a much larger variety of enemies. You had bugs, hydras, demons, crow people, blobs of goo, rats, cats, drakes, walking shells, ghosts, mushrooms, etc. In DS2 you have dudes in armour, and then some more dudes in armour. In DS1 it felt like every area had very specific enemies that were unique and would exist only in that specific area. They were also much more visually intereseting.

6. Increasing the difficulty by just increasing the number of enemies is lazy and boring. It seems like the dev team didn't understand the best thing about DS1. While DS1 had some annoying areas it was for the most part fair and if you were carefull, you could avoid being killed by a pack of enemies. In some places DS2 throws over 8 enemies at you at the same time. And it feels like someone is saying: look at how difficult the game is. It's a real challenge, isn't it?

7. The last two points also apply to the boss fights. The boss design this time seems really unispired compared to DS1. The boss fights in DS2 were made more difficult by throwing multiple opponents at you and adding annoying mobs. This is probably the biggest let down for me. I normally avoid fantasy RPGs because I don't like the setting. But DS1 drew me in, because the enemy design was so creative and weird and so awesome overall. Some enemies are even reused from DS1.


In the end I have to say that DS2 is by no means a bad game but it hasn't really imroved the PvE, lore or visual design in comparison to DS1. On the technical side it's a better PC port than DS1, but with DSFix DS1 isn't really that much worse. In the end I have no interest in playing this game a second time with a different character. Whereas I started a new character with a different focus in DS1, as soon as i finished my 1st play-through and would probably play it again if I had the time.
I hope that DS3 will be better.

reviewText:
My detailed thoughts on Dark Souls 2 and Scholar of the First Sin, you can find here.

Short version:

DARK SOULS II Scholar of the First Sin is a great game that just falls short of being excellent.

Compared to the original version of Dark Souls 2, it's superior in terms of graphics and the gameplay additions do give the game some more depth. BUT the additional content -- mainly one new important NPC and one new secret boss fight -- the shuffling of enemies and items and the LACK of improvements on some of the minor flaws of Dark Souls 2, do not justify the extra $25 for the upgrade from the original Dark Souls 2.

If you've never played Dark Souls/Dark Souls 2 before, buy it!
If you've played Dark Souls 2 before, wait for a discount!
If you've played Dark Souls 2 before and you are a major fan, you've probably already bought it and felt a little ripped off...

reviewText:
It's still not Dark Souls 1, but there's a lot of things they've fixed. (+)
1) You get access to the other two blacksmiths much faster. Ornifex, with the Shadow Woods route opening up earlier, and Bastille's whatshisname, with the Dull Ember located in a less fuky position.
2) Less explodymummies! This includes Grave of Saints, Lost Bastille and Dragon Aerie (there's actually more there, but the whole area becomes skippable).
3) More summons to really break boss AI.
4) The thing that looked like a shortcut in No-Man's Wharf, is now actually a shortcut.

Then there's things that they just changed for no real reason. (-)
1) The area where the non-boss Pursuer appears first time has hollows scattered around (and other places too with many extra fodder enemies for no good reason).
2) There's a firebreath spamming dragon before Ornstein, with the actual Ornstein fight still being pis easy.
3) More of those non-lock-on-able invisible enemies that are almost impossible to hit with certain weapons (spears etc).
4) They lessened the damage you do with Lightning Spears, AND you only have a third of their uses. While still giving the option to buy them an unlimited amount. So for high Faith and Attunement characters, they're still very much spammable, but crippled under 50 Faith characters.

And then there's things they still haven't changed
1) Enemies with weird turntable-y attack tracking (all of them), or attacks connecting before the attack (Gutter dogs), or animation not correspoding what they're actually doing (hollow soldiers attacking with the shield WHILE also guarding with it somehow).
2) Heavy weapons not tracking. They had it right for the DLC weapons, why is Greatsword still messed up?
3) Shrine of Amana.
4) Not enough materials.

Overall it's a better game, not by much, but I recommend it over the original.

reviewText:
Dark Souls II: Scholar of The First Sin
Please note that I will be referencing Dark Souls alot as it is an appropriate title to compare this game to.

Dark Souls is one of the most amazing games I have ever played, I would even go as far as to call it a masterpiece. The game was dripping with atmosphere, spectacular world design, interesting characters with heart touching stories, and tight gameplay with some interesting online features. Now this review isn't for Dark Souls, this is for Dark Souls II: Scholar of The First Sin. Scholar of The First Sin of SoTFS is a re-release of Dark Souls II which was released in April 2014 (For PC.)  The game introduced improved graphics and gameplay, a new world to explore with new enemies and new weapons to fight them with. So here is my opinion on Dark Souls II: Scholar of The First Sin.

Story:The Story in Dark Souls II is about you, an undead who has ventured into Drangleic to find a cure for you undead affliction. I won't continue on as this would spoil the game and chances are; if you're reading this review you have no played the game yet. The story is interesting, and not directly told to the player. One of the greatest part of any souls game is the way the story is presented; the story is hidden in item descriptions and in dialogue with the NPC's. The Dark Souls community has done a great job of uncovering the lore and story of the game.

Gameplay:The gameplay in Dark Souls II is a great improvement on the first game. The movement is made to feel much more fluent and easier to control, the combat is dramatically improved. Dual wielding is now much more viable in the game as dual wielding makes much more sense; R1 and R2 will use the object in your right hand and L1 and L2 will use the object in your left hand, a new power stance feature has been added to the game. The power stance feature allows for a player to activate a whole new move set exclusive to a set of weapons. The way this works is by holding Triangle or Y on the controller when two of the same weapons are equipped. Magic and ranged weapons have been improved by allowing the user to move when using them. One major issue that I have with the game is that the difficulty feels forced, the main way the games attempts to make things difficult is by just throwing more enemies at you. Upon death you are reverted to a hallow; this means you are unable to summon other player to assist you and the players maximum health is lowered, this is rubbish gameplay in my opinion as it negates the desire to explore the world. The playerâ€™s maximum health can be restored with the use of a humane effigy but these items are finite if playing offline. One huge downside is that a controller is highly recommended to play. This is due to the poor control scheme that has been implemented into the game. I use a Dualshock 4 controller to play Dark Souls.

Characters:The characters in Dark Souls 2 are not really all that interesting. The characters lack what made the characters in Dark Souls 2 likeable; the characters in Dark Souls 1 were interesting and had motives of their own. The characters in Dark Souls 2 are boring, for lack of a better term. The emerald herald is the closest thing to an interesting character but she has the personality of toast.

Online Features:The game uses online features in unique ways; players are able to leave notes on the group which other player are able to see, this would be helpful if 99% of the messages did not say â€œtry tongue, but hole.â€ Bloodstains show how another player has died, usually warning players of a dangerous area. Ghost are able to be seen at times, these are other players in their own world. The multiplayer works like this: You are able to summon or be summoned into the world to assist in defeating the environments boss. Upon doing this the player is rewarded with souls and human effigies. A player is also able to invade another playerâ€™s world and fight them in an honourable dual, or a not so honourable 1 vs 3. The online gameplay is quite fun but isnâ€™t required to complete the game.

Environment:This is where I have one of my biggest problems with the game, the world is often bland and makes no sense. In one instance you are at a windmill surrounded by barren wasteland; you beat the boss of the area and continue onwards. You take an elevator upwards and find yourself at a castle made of iron; the castle has sunken into the ground reaching lava. This makes no sense and ruins the player immersion. Dark Souls handled the environments of the game so much better as the world was beautiful to look at with great landscapes to look at. The whole world loops back in on itself creating all these short cuts which just give the game an overall fantastic feeling to it. Dark Souls II is nothing like this as most areas will end in a dead end forcing you to fast travel elsewhere and take a different path.  While the DLC has improved on this and provided much more interesting locations the rest of the game is still a disappointment with much to be desired.

Conclusion:Dark Souls II: Scholar of The First Sin is an amazing game with fun and challenging gameplay, the story is interesting and the online gameplay is very pleasant.  Although I recommend that you play Dark Souls before Dark Souls II: Scholar of The First Sin. You will have a much more enjoyable time with that game, but I am not saying that this game isnâ€™t worth your money. If you enjoyed Dark Souls then this game is worth your money, even if it leaves much to be desired.

Should you buy Dark Souls II: Scholar of The First Sin?

Yes, yes you should.

reviewText:
The original Dark Souls II was a great and challenging game! Scholars is also a very good game but there are many things that just don't work right. It feels too easy in some locations, while it feels pretty unfair in others. Many locations feel unbalanced compared to their setup in the original.

There are some nifty additions there that just don't work. For example placing an enemy on an elevator that should trigger the floorplate to make it move again to surprise the player from behind. Most of the time the enemy doesnt trigger the floorplate. Some other times the enemy leaves the elevator but gets stuck. Enemies get stuck in many places or their pathfinding bugs out.

Is it worth buying the same game again? You will have to start from scratch, because you can't just import existing characters from the original game. You have to unlock all the achievements again of which some where a real challenge (at least for me, King Vendrick for example). I think only hardcore Dark Souls 2 fans should buy this new edition of Dark Souls 2.

reviewText:
A very good game that is at times overshadowed by the success of Dark Souls 1 and marred by some questionable design choices. Excellent for its replay value, player agency and multiplayer interactions. Also a perfect PC port with excellent performance, in contrast to its predecessor.

Dark Souls 2 introduced a lot of improvements to the series that are often overlooked. The weapon upgrade system is no longer so obtuse that it punishes players that don't read guides. The implementation of weapons is excellent and eschews the fairly pointless slow attacks that were present in the first game (ie: black knight sword R2). Movement and control as a whole feels very smooth and has been improved to the point that DS1 actually feels somewhat unrefined by comparison.

Perhaps the most important improvement is the sheer volume of this game. Compared to DS1 there are more weapons, armor sets, rings (and ring slots), spells, and the areas are longer and more numerous. All of these factors contribute to greater replayability and more rewarding experiences in multiplayer. In my experience the limit of ten character slots is not nearly enough for the immense value you can get out of this game. An online community that often prioritises fashion over utility speaks volumes of the creativity of the Dark Souls 2 player base and the game itself.

The overall experience is somewhat inconsistent in terms of presentation and quality. At its best Scholar of the First Sin is visually impressive, but still retains the lacking appearance of some areas such the Shaded Woods and Earthen Peak. Many areas of this game lack the detail present in other Souls games. Rather than presenting a location that people are supposed to have lived in, many areas  consist of featureless rooms and hallways with varying placements of items and enemies. The lack of small details detract from the overall believability of the world, which is undoubtedly a significant part of the series. The music is also a mixed bag, ranging from the greatly thought provoking and compelling to the uninspired and generic.

There are some other issues with the game. The enemies often ignore the rules placed on human players, such as stamina and poise. Defining a 'fair challenge' can be difficult when you are expected to fight enemies many times your size, but these instances are a simple lack of internal consistency, which makes the game feel cheap and unrewarding. Conversely many bosses are far too easy to overcome, such as the Covetous Demon or Giant Lord. Unfortunately in Scholar of the First Sin almost any area that could be considered a challenge has at least one overpowered NPC summon available to trivialize the area. The addition of an NPC white phantom to Belfry Sol, a PVP area without a boss, is lamentably stupid.

Despite the many criticisms I could list about balance and design this is still an excellent game. When I got all of the achievements I thought I had seen everything and was done. As it happens I could enjoy over a hundred more hours playing this game. There is always a new weapon to try out, a new character you can make, an enemy attack you've probably never seen before and endless multiplayer elements to enjoy. Even though it appears that Dark Souls 3 will be great improvement for the series, I will look back on this game fondly.

reviewText:
I will keep this as short as I can so everyone can just go through it. Infact I will only mention the points that I think have a real bad impact on this game. This review has nothing to do with gameplay or bossfights or anything. So If you want to inform yourself about that: Go to a different review.

(I want to add that I actually like this game alot. Its quite good even though it doesnt reach DS1 of course. It hurts me to say this about the game as It does take away from the goodnes it should present you)

So what do I want to say? The game is good but the community is rather â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. I mean this doesnt mean that you cant meet nice people. There alot. Just that the bad apples cover about 85% of the damn tree.

Now here is why I say this:

The games concept is known and easy to understand.

You as the player have three ways of playing the game. Singleplayer, Coop, PVP.

Singlerplayer mainly requires you, leveling your character which can get boring.

Coop means that you can summon other people for jolly cooperation.

PVP however is the big bad of these three styles.

Normaly PVP is known to be just good old fighting. Some do it with honor and bow and have a skillfull fight and some rather try the sneaky approach to kill you when you expect it the least. Absolutly fine.

What isnt fine however is the amount of people abusing what the game gave them to basically always win. And this has nothing to do with cheating or hacking. It also doesnt have to do with your level or soulmemory.

This is about using weapons or armor, hexes or miracles to an extent that you have an unfair advantage over the other player. Like using the spampier (Rapier Spam) on heavy armored people to just stunlock them into submission until they die. Or using Hexes that one hit kill you if you dont roll away fast enough. And even if you do you get instakilled by the next attack.



The next thing about this whole thing goes to the forums. I have been on both game forums for about 4 times. And every time I did regret going there. Once I had a simple discussion about what people think to be the better game and why. Another time I asked what they would think would be the best system in DS3 for Matchmaking. In both cases I have stated my opinion which was: 1. I like DS2 more over DS1 because of the graphics, places and Weapons. 2. I thought that a combination of both systems would be the best.

In both cases it did not take long for the people to run in and ruin my post. A literal â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥torm within seconds.

So what does that mean? Is the game bad now? No. Its decent. Not as good as DS1 but still good and enjoyable to play. IN COOP. Just dont complain about anything on the forums or have a suggestion to make things better. Also git gud and be a havelchipmunk.

No in all seriousnes: The game is good but the community of this game is utter â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. You can find nice people that you can play with, have found a few myself, but if you find 10 nice people you will find 10000 bad people. PVP has been ruined because of this community and its mentality.

reviewText:
When I first downloaded this game, I was hyped to play it because gameplay videos and word of mouth made the game super fun. But when I started playing, I found out that there is just as much bad as there is good in this game.

It's got a bunch of good parts and a bunch of bad parts, and overall, I've found the game to be okay at best, a troll game with an acquired taste at worst. Playing Dark Souls 1 makes me happy. This game, meh. To repeat a phrase for the 10000th time, this game is good, but it pales in comparison to Dark Souls 1.

I can play DS1 sober, drunk, happy, or sad, wakeful, tired, and always find a way to have fun. But in this game, some stuff is just douchey, some stuff a chore, but there are some enjoyable pieces if you stick around. For instance, looting and fashion souls are the highlights of this game. Also performs very well, being lag free on a good PC, with flawless multiplayer connection. Overall, I give this game a rating of 6.
