reviewText:
I like to write reviews while I'm playing a game ^-^ I NEEDED to get this review out because this is one of my favorite series' of all time.
Everyone knows these games are punishing, and if you're not careful and patient, and cautious every single second, you WILL be punished for it. Even I fall victim to that when I decide to stay somewhere for hours farming items that are SUPPOSED to make the game even harder than it already is, and it's not even very hard for me.

This game (Still not sure WHAT the differences are between normal DS2 and SotFS are) is incredibly beautiful. Sometimes, I like to remove the HUD and just take screenshots of the amazing sceney and sights all around the game. But, with about a year of rebalancing gameplay and graphics and all that, this is supposed to run and look so much better than the original DS2, with so much more story, too. But that's aside the point:

It's incredibly beautiful, marvelously realistic, and, in EVERY way, incredible. It's magical. In meaning and pure essence, the story this game tells of is crazy deep. It's one of those games that can just...change your perception of life, and/or gaming in absolute general. FromSoftware didn't take long to get noticed with their first Souls game for the PS3, Demon's Souls. My own soul was instantly bought by them when I tried the game myself, and I've been a doofus fan ever since.
AGAIN, off topic :/

If you're just not patient, and want to rush through this game, RUSHING WILL GET YOU NOWHERE. THE GAME GETS HARDER AND HARDER THE MORE YOU DIE. YOU WILL LOSE EVERYTHING (as the opening cutscene basically tells you. But great reward awaits you with every single thing you do in the game. Seriously...

If you're new to Dark Souls 2, and at this point in time [unless it goes on sale here again], I suggest you buy it on a console. It's cheaper, and, on the next generation consoles, will support MUCH better graphics and flow, resulting in MUCH more efficient gameplay. The requirements for playing the game on a PC aren't too strict. Many reviews mention how smoothly the game presents itself on their PCs. Same goes for mine, and my laptop is about average when it comes to gaming, I'd like to think.

Immense satisfaction awaits. If you've never even tried a Souls game, Go ahead and get a taste of Dark Souls: Prepare to Die edition and have all that nice extra stuff included (which I still don't know what's different about. These games can be very enjoyable if you watch yourself and take the game seriously at every moment. I want to see more players love this game instead of hate it.

reviewText:
First of all, I have been playing all Souls games to get a feel for them individually. Dark Souls 2 seems to be the ugly cow in the farm mostly do to the fact that the original game director was busy with Bloodborne. Well, I must say that is not an issue and the team responsible for making this game did a great job. In the presentation department, the world seems fuller. Also, there are more npcs this time around that breath life into the world. Story, while still vague, is presented in better fashion than the previous game and as you explore along, some areas really depict a believable history in the World of Drangleic. Giants, fallen kings, betryal, war, humanity. The world has rich lore and it's sold pretty well, if you look for it.

Combat feels smooth, new animations look good and are varied. It's a bit slower though and character feels heavier when performing certain animations which I don't prefer but it's not a big issue. Had problems with the lock-on not locking on when I wanted to nor changing targets which is annoying but it can be managed.

The biggest downside for me is in the boss battles. There are more this time around but they have been stripped down and eased up from previous game. Most of the bossess designs seem unespired and only a few stood out. It does not compare to the Original game where every boss was memorable. While some would be easy but they where still impactfull. Here, not so much.

On a lighter note, I have to give MAYOR props for the guys who optimized and configured this game. Game runs really smooth and in the highest settings. The original Dark Souls suffered from mayor frame rate drops and I experienced the same in Dark Souls 3 even on lowest settings. Goes to show that the team behind this game, did a great job without the direction of THE BIG MAN."

To conclude
date: the game is great regardless of some minor let downs. Pvp is an improvement. A number of areas where desgined as battle arenas for online play and serve as interesting playgrounds. Some areas are challenging to traverse like Iron Keep and the game changes tone as the game goes on. The world may not be the masterful design the Original was but
recommended: it's still a world worth exploring with some amazing set pieces. Also. all three chunks of dlc are superb and challenging. Great stuff here."

reviewText:
A belated review for Dark Souls II. I actually played this originally on the PS3 (got the platinum for it too) and loved it, before picking it up for a second time on PC. Dark Souls II unfairly received a lot of flak for not being produced by Miyazaki, but the 'Team B' crew still did a fantastic job.

I loved the locations. You had your fire and ice settings, along with very green, very dark settings, and then some almost blind areas (Shaded Woods) which were quite enjoyable to travel through. The overall world layout could have been done better as some of it didn't quite make sense. For example travelling up from Harvest Valley to the lava filled area of Iron Keep doesn't make any sense geographically.

The new Adaptability stat was an odd inclusion. It seemed quite unnecessary, with most players getting it to 20 and then forgetting about it.

Magic was really well done, with sorcery, faith, pyro and dark magic all being totally viable playstyle options. Faith did take some heavy nerfs later on which was a shame, but to be fair it was probably a little OP at launch, with Lightning Spears able to take out most mobs and bosses quite easily.

The network side of things was really solid. I have almost zero issues with summoning other players or being summoned myself. I was definitely not a fan of the new Souls Memory mechanic. I think it did more harm than good with it really limiting how much co-op you could do before being out of range of other players.

The three DLC's were all absolutely excellent, definitely worth the asking price. All of them had brilliantly crafted levels with lots of shortcuts and secrets to unlock, and all had some really well designed and very challenging bosses.

Anyway Dark Souls II is a solid addition to the series and highly recommended. Not as good as the first Dark Souls IMO but still very much worth a play.

reviewText:
Definitely recommended for those who do NOT already own Dark Souls II. If you already own the original, then it's honestly not that worth it.

The only major difference between the original and this remastered version are the different enemy placements, ugpraded enemy AI, and the slightly tweaked graphics upgrade. There is also a new random NPC invader called Forlorn that will periodically invade you throughout your journey and the Pursuer will now attack you in new surprising locations as well.

Other than that, however, you're basically paying an upgrade fee for very little differences.

Nevertheless, it's perfect for those who do not own the original DS2. This remaster is the definitive version and it'd be a poor choice to buy the original over the remaster.

reviewText:
It was about an hour in, once we reached Heideâ€™s Tower of Flame, when we realised that Scholar Of The First Sin is exactly what we wanted it to be. Essentially a rejig of the GamesMaster Game Of The Year 2014 winner we know and love, this current-gen re-release does much more than simply serve up the PC versionâ€™s visuals with the stellar DLC collection.
Alongside such admirable feats, Scholar also manages to force those who have passed through the corridors, caves and climes of Drangleic hundreds of times to rethink their approaches. It forces us, basically, to sheath our cĞ¾cksure trail blazing and raise our shields in sweet trepidation once more. It does so with admirable, minutely architectured and always surprising design.
Take the aforementioned Heideâ€™s Tower. Previously this area was home to hulking, bearded statue types, whose attacks would carve vast swathes of the air around them to get at you. We mastered these chaps through hours of failed attempts. We know when to pull them, when to roll, when to backpedal and when to get our hits in. Here in Scholar, these enemies are augmented by the Heide Knights themselves.
These white-clad warriors sit passively until they are attacked, at which point theyâ€™ll harangue you with lightning-fast swipes and hard-to-read strikes. Youâ€™ll need to measure up whether you want to take on these guys or leave them sitting forlorn as you muscle through the rest of the area. Of course, thereâ€™s always the risk that one of the wide-ranging strikes of your hairier foes will tap one of them and trigger their aggressionâ€¦ Itâ€™s a wonderfully Soulsian balance of risk versus reward.
And - naturally, knowing FromSoftâ€™s ways by now - thereâ€™s an extra twist to this game of will-you-wonâ€™t-you. Best the area boss and suddenly, laden with his tasty souls as you are, all of the Heide Knights you left behind will awaken and chase you across the map. A masterful touch that will have you both agape and legging it to the nearest bonfire. You may have bested the area, but whenever you head back to journey through it again itâ€™ll be more dangerous than ever. This happens again and again as you venture through this reborn Drangleic. Weâ€™ve picked an area near the start of the game to focus on here, as we donâ€™t want to spoil the surprises that lie in wait beyond.
Perhaps a little less surprising is that Dark Souls 2 on current-gen outstrips its last-gen counterpart at almost every turn. The most immediately appreciable factor is that frame rate. At 60fps itâ€™s silky smooth, so much so that we actually found ourselves having to slightly alter the speed at which we played. The character models and environments are generally a lot crisper now, too, with minute details, such as the embossed covering of a Twin Dragon Greatshield or the leathery dimples on your wanderer coat really popping out.
Itâ€™s not all perfect, however. Certain enemies, we noticed, still have jarring frame rate drops when theyâ€™re far away from your character. The boars that charge about near the Brightstone Cove bonfire in Tseldora, for example, will jitter about when more than a few paces away. Also some areas, such as the Shaded Woods, donâ€™t really benefit from the new visual crisp-ification. Remember when Silent Hill 2 got remade in HD and suddenly that horrible fog wasnâ€™t quite as foggy? A similar thing happens here and enemies that were once invisible, and therefore terrifying, are now clear to see, taking away their hold on us somewhat.
Before you start shaking your head, letâ€™s reel it in. On Dark Souls 2â€™s initial launch last year a horde of gamers took to the interwebs to rail against a lighting feature which was apparently removed from the final game, yet had been shown off pre-release. Itâ€™s back. In Scholar youâ€™ll find yourself entering areas which are jet black without torchlight to guide you. Whereas once these flaming brands were used sparingly, at least until the second DLC pack, now youâ€™ll find yourself praising the sun every time you pick up a Flame Butterfly, a newly essential item used to light a torch without trailing back to a sconce or bonfire.
This new lighting system means that there are, on occasions, entirely different techniques required when approaching certain areas. Where once you would cut through a tight corridor with caution thrown to the wind, now youâ€™ll have to use all your senses to pick up sounds of movement beyond your torchflame or the slight indication that thereâ€™s something waiting in the darkness.
It can be nail-ruining stuff, especially as many of the enemies you wouldnâ€™t normally meet until later in the game now get up in your grill much, much earlier. Heck, one enemy you come across in the Shaded Woods canâ€™t usually be spotted until youâ€™ve restarted in New Game+ in the original version.
We admit it's a tired term, but the word â€˜definitiveâ€™ really does apply to this version of Dark Souls 2. Is this the best place for newcomers to get involved? Yes. Many of the graphical foibles that we forgave in the original version have now been ironed out. Is it worth veterans unsheathing their greatswords once more? Yes. The returning lighting system and artfully re-placed enemy encounters ensure you can tap into that sense of discovery, foreboding and mastery that was once so prevalent and has since become rote.
We kept thinking of Fallout and Skyrim when we weâ€™re playing Scholar. You know how sometimes when youâ€™ve played those games for a while you feel like starting over from scratch? You can drop all of your inventory off at a house, or even load a new game and just walk in another direction to see whatâ€™s there. In Dark Souls itâ€™s your own experience that gives your character most of its power, rather than arbitrary numbers attached to gear found on the way. You canâ€™t lose all of that knowledge; youâ€™re stuck with it. By releasing this version, FromSoft has allowed players a chance to truly rediscover one of the most involving game worlds in existence. And that is quite something to behold.

reviewText: Dark Souls II: Scholar of the First Sin is the new and improved version of Dark Souls II. Being the successor to Dark Souls, one would be correct in expecting an excellent game with refined mechanics, excellent world building and exquisite boss fights. Dark Souls II delivers in its PvP and online matchmaking mechanics, but pales in comparison to Dark Souls' PvE and world building.\n\nThe overall layout of Dark Souls II's world is incoherent and a lot of times does not make any sense whatsoever. reviewText:
I have played and beat all games in the franchise more then once except for BB and i can honestly say this is my favorite of the bunch. I really believe its what your priorties are for a souls game. If you like cohesive world design, shortcuts, and story elements souls 1 will be your favorite. If you like awesome boss fights and fantastic combat that extends to pvp then souls 3 will be your favorite. If you like a segmented game with more cinematic boss fights and interesting game mechanics that are not present in the other games demons may be your favorite. But if you like large games with lots of replay, a massive amount of equally viable play syles, massive well crafted levels with awesome secrets, well placed loot drops, interesting covenants including a non-multiplayer covenant and a game that is harder then souls 3 but you don't have to have that bs 4 directional roling from souls one then this is the souls game for you.

I know mine is an unpopular opinion and I can see why anyone would say any of the games are the best as they are all truly fantastic with each having its own unique strengths. Even if people say this is the worst souls game most of those people would still tell you that it is head and shoulder above all other action rpgs not in the souls series. So give this one a try if your a souls vet who passed on this because of what people have said about it then give it a shot. If you havnt tryed the series yet and want the best entry point in the series I would direct you to Souls 3 as it is the easist in the series and thus the best entry point for newbies.

So give this one a try it's an awesome game it may end up being your favorite in the series as well.

reviewText:
If you haven't played this before, you can go ahead and immediately buy this. No questions asked, just do it.

If you've played the original Dark Souls 2 (with DLC) and are wondering what Scholar of the First Sin added, then the answer is... well... not a lot, honestly. A few enemies are rearranged and certain areas that didn't make sense before (i.e. Hiede's Tower of Flame) are now upgraded to be a bit more interesting. There's also an NPC added who tosses out a whole bunch of lore every now and again, along with a new boss fight and ending. But other than that, it's essentially the same game.

On one hand it's cool because I can safely say that all of Scholar of the First Sin's changes are for the better. The little tweaks to the enemies make the game flow a lot better and the added lore makes the game make much more sense than it did before while still retaining its mystery.

On the other hand, it's still pretty much the same game. The enemies are still placed roughly the same as they've always been and the new boss isn't even particularly difficult. And nothing's really stopping you from watching the new ending on Youtube.

So what I'd say is that if you've been contemplating another Dark Souls 2 playthrough, then this is worth buying. But if you weren't thinking of that already, then give it a pass.

And if you haven't played DS2 at all, then buy this immediately.

reviewText:
After playing through NG/NG+ and after a good amount of PvP I can finally give a proper review.

Pros:

- Improvements in graphics and sound. The textures are crispier and and effects are nice to watch at. Shrine of Amana is even more beautiful and pure eye candy. The sound quality has improved and there has been additions in atmospheric sounds. There's also already some SweetFX presets for SotFS available if the graphical improvements are not enough for you. Modding with Gedosato is currently not possible, but I'm pretty sure this will be updated soon.

- New Enemy and Item placements. As a vetaran in DS2, I ran into the game really cheeky, not expecting much of a surpise and got stopped abruptly. New enemy placements are smart, but also mean and requires you to think things out before going in blind. Hell, I even been spooked several times. Item changes give you more variety how to play as you can get different weapons now early. It also requiers you to search as the majority of Estus Flask Shards and Sublime Bone Dusts have been moved aswell.

- Improved enemy AI. Enemy now chase you across the map and won't let go of you unless you enter a boss or different area. This requires you to kill them. Don't try to speedrun through the game, especially on your first playthrough as you will fail missarbly. Instead of finding only stationary enemies you will also find some enemies patroling through areas. It's a nice little effect and helps making the world more lively.

- More NPC invaders. All of the NPC invaders in the original game were rather stupid and easy to kill by just simply stunlocking them. They didn't pose any threat whatsoever. SotFS now adds several new NPC invaders who will invade you throughout your playthrough. The most notorious one: Forlorn. He might invade you at any giving time and in any place that is invandable. I had him invading me in Iron Keep while I was fighting off several Alonne Knights and that cheeky buttface backstabbed me in the meantime.. Anyways, the new additions are smarter, do more damage and are actually a threat. However, this is a double-edged sword as those invaders have a huge amount of health and perform strange acts, such as rolling out of my riposte after a parry (???).

- More Lore. Many items desciptions have been updated to tell the lore of the game better than previously. Majority of the translations errors have been fixed aswell. A nice change for people who care about the lore of the Dark Souls universe.

- Still a superior NG+. You can tell me whatever you want, but Dark Souls 2 is one of the few games to date that has a well done and rewarding NG+. All of the previous Souls games and even BloodBorne NG+'s have only adjustments to the health and damage of enemies and the amount of Souls. There's nothing new otherwise. Dark Souls 2 however had from the start on a good NG+. First of all, you have the choice of going to NG+ and not beeing automaticly thrown in. You will find more unique enemies in addition to beeing tougher, including some red spirits here and there. And you will find unique weapons and armor bound to NG+. Now ofcourse not everyone is keen to go NG+, so you have the choice of using a Bonfire Ascetic in certain areas to get some of that stuff.


Cons:

- Durability bug persists. Let's start of with this one as this is still one of the biggest issues of the game. The durability of your equipment is tied to your FPS (frames per second). DS2 was created for the consoles first and then ported over to the PC and had it's FPS unlocked to 60 instead of 30 FPS. The durability degredation has not been adjusted to 60 FPS. Means your equipment will degrade twice as fast, which is for obvious reason a bug. That it has not been fixed yet up to this date (1 year later!), especially on this director's cut, boggles my mind. Now there are few ways how to deal with this. First of all, you could lock your FPS to 30, which obviously no one would like to. Another solution" would be to have more than 1 weapon with you and enough repair power. You should also avoid hitting coprses

it's pretty good.  if you want a first souls game, ds3 is really only best once you've played ds1, so ds2 is a decent place to start if you don't want to deal with the hassle of setting up ds1 (but if you get hooked on ds2 you'll probably be fine with dealing with that hassle to get more dark souls).  Just don't start depraved in ds2 if this is your first souls game...

combat wise, this game feels a little more deliberate with your rolls than ds1 or ds3, kinda like always having a somewhat faster ds1 mid-roll.  rolling while locked on targets isn't angled relative to the target, which is really nice (no more rolling off cliffs just because you had the audacity to try to roll while locked on).

level design wise, the individual areas seem well designed, but the overall world isn't nearly as impressive as the interconnected world of ds1 (ds3 also suffers from this, but perhaps to a somewhat lesser extent).

lore wise ds2 is somewhat off on its own compared to ds1/ds3, but it's sufficient to make the world feel fleshed out.

reviewText:
With some time spent both in Dark Souls 2 and SotFS, here are my two cents on both games.

First off, the differences between both games from the top of my head:

Dark Souls 2 had a few paid DLCs that are included in SotFS.
Console players got SotFS for FREE, PC users have to pay for it.
SotFS includes additional enemies (some of which will revisit you a few times);
Some items and bonfires have been relocated, so if you've played Dark Souls 2 before, you might want to comb through each area and make sure you aren't missing anything.

NB: Dark Souls 2 characters will NOT work on SotFS and vice versa!

Pros:
- Way better optimized than Dark Souls, The game runs a stable 60 FPS. Even with the nearly mandatory dsfix, Dark Souls has certain areas that lower your framerate significantly. I do not recall such performance issues to happen in SotFS/DS2 (I might be wrong, however).

- Fluidity - the combat feels a lot more fluid when compared to Dark Souls, animations seem improved, invincibility frames when rolling depend on a certain stat. You will often get hit even if it seems like you would've dodged the attack unless if you invest levels in said stat.

- Fresh start - New areas to explore and a new story to learn.

- Additional enchants - Can enchant your weapon in effects such as poison, without the use of rotten pine resin.

- Warping between bonfires - you can now go from one bonfire to the other without acquiring a certain item.

Cons:

- Soul memory - One of the biggest turn-offs in this game. The more souls you spend on leveling and purchasing items, the higher your soul memory becomes. There is no way to reduce the same. It would at least make sense if the soul memory used for temporary/usable items would not count or would be reduced upon their use. From now on, your character's level will not matter, and what initially seemed like a good idea unfortunately is quite a bane for most players.

- Frustrating areas - Just like Blighttown from the old game, there are certain areas you just want to get over with as soon as possible.

- Invasions - you only get cracked blue and red eye orbs, which cost a lot.

- Hollowing - hollowing works so every time you die, you lose 5% of your total HP, and the effect stacks. While you get a neat visual change with each of your deaths, your health is permanently lowered, down to 50% HP. To revert this, you need to use a human effigy, which restores your human form. Alternatively, you can become a white or gray phantom and successfully assist the host - upon doing so, you are returned to your human form along with some goodies and souls. NB: You can still get invaded while you're a hollow, however you cannot invade others unless you're in your human form.

- Design - the game can feel very linear and unlike in Dark Souls, Miyazaki who's work is revered by the Souls community has not worked at all on Dark Souls 2, nor on SotFS.

- Hitboxes - Infuriating. Example: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kVTXeuHrjvE


Verdict: Dark Souls 2: SotFS is a decent game, however I would personally strongly recommend buying the first one. Why get Dark Souls? Because it's more fun, has a much better story and doesn't feel as linear.

If you have Dark Souls 2 with none of the DLCs just get SotFS when it's on sale (if you don't mind starting over).

reviewText:
Heres my quick breakdown for this amazing game, continue past the PROS & CONS for my full review.

---PROS---

-A huge and beautifully designed world
-Exciting and engaging combat
-Detailed and challenging bosses and mobs
-A stupendous amount of weapons
-Entrancing music
-Friendly and helpful community
-Fair and fun PvP

---CONS---

-Lack of variety in bosses
-Online connectivity issues for co-op and PvP (Sometimes)
-Massive learning curve for non Dark Souls players (Not an issue if you like a challenge)

All in all im giving this game a 9.5/10


-Full review-


I have nothing but praise (the sun) for this game. What a fantastic and thrilling adventure. It grips you from the start and never lets go. Although the game can be stressful at times, especially when you're stuck on that one boss you've tried to beat a thousand times, it more than makes up for it the moment that you beat that boss or an area. It takes the brilliant qualities of Dark Souls (1) and improves upon them in many ways.

For one this game has such a mesmerising environment. Many times i found my self stepping back from the grind and just being awe struck at the beauty and detail thats went into this vast and exciting world. From the thrilling brilliance of the Sun on the sea in Majula to the eerily dark feel of the Black gulch's green glow, it has it all. The terrain were battles take place plays a more important role aswell with it being much easier to fall off a ledge or get backed into a corner and ive had my tumbles in this game with more than a few bosses and mobs, talking about you Dragonrider.

The mobs in this game accentuate the grand landscapes in this game with their impressive details and suiting characteristics. They're much more difficult in my opinion than this games predecossor and theres alot more of them than compared to the original Dark Souls 2. A few of them present a challenge to match that of a boss which emphasizes the difficulty of this game and adds to the relief when you finally beat an area. A memorable moment for me was getting chased by a million spiders in an attempt to fight their boss, the sheer panic and resolve i was feeling in that moment is a highlight for me in this game. They are beautiful in their own way and they fill their respective environment quite naturally and fit in with the characteristics of the boss they protect.

I found the bosses in this game very rewarding, particularly the DLC bosses. They were exceptionally designed and very challenging. Though the main theme in their deisign seemed to knight related there were a few that were outstanding such as The Dukes dear Freja. There are times when you're fighting that one grand boss and you can feel your heart racing and you find yourself drawing closer to the screen in such a tense moment trying to get that killing hit and when you finally beat it that wash of victory that comes over you makes all the struggling, all the blood, sweat and tears so worth it. And then its back to the grind for the next area.

The co-op in the game feels vastly more improved upon from the previous Dark Souls (1) introducing a new way to connect based on whats called soul memory. I liked the introduction of different types of summoned allies such as shades which expanded the range of help you can get. The PvP was exciting and many aspects of this games PvP match closely to that of Dark Souls (1) which meant you never lost your favrite covenant. There are alot of options and ways to go about PvP to make it accessible to a much larger amount of players.

There is a MASSIVE amount of weapons and armor in this game that cater to a great amount of fighting styles. They are very well contructed in how they look and how they behave in combat. There are the extreme forms of both heavy tank with 2 handed great hammer to nimble backstabber wielding 2 swift daggers with everything you can think of in between. I found the magic and spells in this game to be very elegent. There were alot to choose from for each individual style whether that be magnificent spells and angelic miracles to tenebrous hexes and wrathful pyromancies. They all add this sense of individuality to the game as you choose what your character is going to be.

The 'story' in this game requires attention to detail which can take a few play throughs to fully understand. I very much enjoyed my experience with this games story and it made me feel apart of its world. Plus i really liked option of 2 endings which i very much appreciated.

This fantastic game brought out so many great feelings from within me and although i got stressed, annoyed and angry they were all dwarfed by the explosion of happiness when i finally beat this game. No other game series quite captured that same affect for me making this one of the best games ive played.

If you're reading this i HIGHLY recommend you get this game, more so if you're a fan of RPG's and more so than that if you liked Dark Souls (1). Its different in quite a few ways from its predecessor but change isnt always a bad thing and this is a case were it was done right. Praise the Sun!

reviewText: Dark Souls II: Sotfs is...well, it's a game. If you're looking for gameplay and storytelling similar to Dark Souls I, you're probably better off buying a PS4 and Bloodborne. If you're looking for an active PvP/Co-op community, you'll most likely find it here. Save for the occasional Bad Apple and/or hacker, the PvP/Co-op community is quite good. Would I reccomend Scholar in general? Yes, yes I would. Would I reccomend it for a hardcore Souls player? Probably not. Anyone that has played Dark Souls I for any extended period of time and has experience in handling it, you'll probably struggle at first, saying things like, 'How did that hit me?', or 'I was nowhere near that!' when dodging attacks. Enemies track you very well, almost frustratingly so. I feel like I shouldnt have to mention it, since it says so, but have a controller ready, as its PC controls are garbage. If you like the Souls games for what they are, then you'll probably like Sotfs. If you've tried Dark Souls II before, on PS3, 360, or PC, and didn't like it, this won't change your mind. Although if you hated it because the graphics were bad before, this might change your mind, but if that's what you value games for, shouldn't you be playing Crysis, instead?

Dark Souls II: Scholar of the First Sin is the second draft of From Software's Dark Souls II. It's absolutely gorgous, and its variety of landscapes and enemies is stunning. But aside from how freaking beautiful this game looks if you're a long time Souls fan you're going to notice something different about Dark Souls II and SoTFS.

Is this game good? Yes, it is. Even for all its â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥t it's easier than Dark Souls or Demon's Souls. Is it better than Dark Souls or Demon's Souls? No, it's not. If you're a Souls fan you'll take any bit you can get. If you're a newie to the franchise looking at picking this game up because it's newer and prettier, trust me, Dark Souls: Prepare to Die is going to be far more satisfying and is going to frusterate you less.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------

reviewText:
Scholar of the first sin is what Dark souls 2 should have been from the beginning.

A difficult game with enemies placed strategically related to lore, rather than randomly scattered.

The revised Soul Memory system, while by no means perfect, is significantly better than the original DKS2 experience for PvP and PvE players alike.

The lore of the game feels more consistent now, with new dialogue and item descriptions subtly improving the overall experience for lore-hunters.

However, there are drawbacks.

SOTFS is even more poorly balanced than DKS2 was originally - sometimes it feels like they have just arbitrarily thrown X amount of enemies in a room without any thought for fairness.

Areas like Shrine of Amana were not reworked to be fairer to the player, instead punishing the player for things outside of their control.

Moreover for original DKS2 owners on PC, upgrading to SOTFS is a very poor deal indeed.

A rare genre in itself, this game could have been better, but also much worse. Overall, whilst a flawed experience and not as good as Dark Souls 1, Dark Souls 2 is definitely worth a try if you like punishing [to the point of often unfair / frustrating] Dark Fantasy RPGs.

reviewText:
This game is awesome ! Simple as that!

The game is awesome and worths every single penny.

reviewText:
Worth Every Cent
Everyone likes different aspects of the Souls games. Whether it be the Lore, level design, combat, PvP, weapon and armour varieties or just the challenge, these games excel beyond most games in their extremely well thought out mechanics and calculated strategies.

I don't tend to replay even complexed games, but Dark Souls with it's ability to create custom builds that you really develop and manufacture with limited resources makes for alot of replayability. Not to mention optional bosses and exploring hidden areas.

Granted so far in the series the online play has been at times difficult with it's limited netcode, but when you do manage to co-op with friends or fight another player the experiences make up for the terrible connection recipe.

The games also have a great atmosphere made up buy the minimalistic music and isolated sound effects you really use sound the assess your surroundings. The sounds of an unseen enemy sneaking around a corner always keeps you on your toes.

I really appreciate SOTFS's improved graphics and tweaks to the levels and enemies aswell, it just makes it even better.

Pro's
Integrated Online play
Replayability
Intense combat
Colossal world
Mass of weapons and spells
Tough rewarding optional challenges
And the list goes on...

Con's
Trouble at time connecting with friends.

10/10

This game is very fun. Make sure that when you play it you listen to calming music to keep you from throwing your controller or punching a hole in the wall, because it has tons of BS. Now, this isn't the original DS2, so there are areas that are a lot harder than the original, such as Heide's Tower of Flame. There are also a lot of terribly designed zones where their tactic of making it hard was to just swarm you with enemies, like the new Iron Keep. Though it lacks the level design and story cohesiveness and depth that DS1 had, it's still a fun game with many beautiful and awe-inspiring areas.

As I said, though, prepare to be assaulted from all sides. There are lots of enemies in this game, and all of them are faster than the previous game. Poise isn't as effective in the second installment of the Dark Souls series, and the key to progress is rolling.

reviewText:
Worth Every Cent
Everyone likes different aspects of the Souls games. Whether it be the Lore, level design, combat, PvP, weapon and armour varieties or just the challenge, these games excel beyond most games in their extremely well thought out mechanics and calculated strategies.

I don't tend to replay even complexed games, but Dark Souls with it's ability to create custom builds that you really develop and manufacture with limited resources makes for alot of replayability. Not to mention optional bosses and exploring hidden areas.

Granted so far in the series the online play has been at times difficult with it's limited netcode, but when you do manage to co-op with friends or fight another player the experiences make up for the terrible connection recipe.

The games also have a great atmosphere made up buy the minimalistic music and isolated sound effects you really use sound the assess your surroundings. The sounds of an unseen enemy sneaking around a corner always keeps you on your toes.

I really appreciate SOTFS's improved graphics and tweaks to the levels and enemies aswell, it just makes it even better.

Pro's
Integrated Online play
Replayability
Intense combat
Colossal world
Mass of weapons and spells
Tough rewarding optional challenges
And the list goes on...

Con's
Trouble at time connecting with friends.

10/10

reviewText:
This game is awesome ! Simple as that!

Here I could experience the true feeling of progression. I used to stay hours trying to do perfect runs on specific segments of the game, getting beating down, rage quitting and coming back later. After you defeat everything on the perfect way, you move on and repeat the cycle.  Its funny how you easily beat areas that you struggled and then realizes: I progressed and I got better.

And then, there is the lore, the Hollowing, the Undeads , the Ambient... The hopelessness of being destined to hollow is sad, And the fact that I had to start the game , meaning that I abandoned and hallowed a character makes me feel deeply reflective about DS2 world and lore.

The game is awesome, a piece of art. Don't get discouraged by the game difficulty , its temporary and you will die, and you will improve and progress.

The game is awesome and worths every single penny.

reviewText:
Original released version was very fun, good visuals and gameplay that swings from fun to hell, depends on your action or accidental button push that puts you to your 10th death or worse.

This version is almost the same just enemies moved around and put more in some areas + other NPC (Dark Spirirts) spawn at some points and attack you, while its happening can other player also invade you if you are unlucky, and they show as red coloured characters and are called Dark Phantom.

You can either summon or be summoned as a Phantom, when summoned its about helping the Summoner in that world, when successful in helping you get lots of souls which are the games currency in basically everything, from weapons to armour and including leveling up, and everytime you level up a stat (Vigor, endurance, vitality and so on) the next level up will cost more souls.
So you have to do alot of grinding in the game or go on to the bosses and get some from assistance of others or npc.

I havent reached the DLC areas yet but hear only good stuff about them. This version is visually updated also since its running on dx11. The original was in dx9. And I can see the difference and I prefer this one.

I recommend this game, first of all if you dont have the original and or have it but not the dlc, i bought this through steam sale when the price was low about 10 dollars to upgrade because i have the original.
If you never have played the original DS2 and love challenges and frustrations, this game is for ye.

reviewText:
I thoroughly enjoyed the Scholar of the First Sin edition.
The gameplay and feel were exactly like Dark Souls / Demon Souls.
Loved the multi-route options and the ability to skip optional bosses.
In this game edition, the developers had the foresight to add a large number of computer allies to support you, in the case where the co-op playerbase dwindled.

One major issue I had with the game was the the decision to limit the number of eligible players you could co-op with. You were limited to those who've only acquired a certain lifetime amount of 'currency' that was similar to your lifetime currency count. I felt this was a terrible decision as oftentimes you would permanently lose large amounts of spendible currency and these would still count towards your lifetime currency count. This meant that the more currency you lost, the weaker you were considered in relation to other players who didn't lose their currency. In the same thread, it meant that gaining too much currency blocked you from playing with the larger playerbase.

Despite the co-op matchmaking gripes. This game is a solid 10/10 for it's gameplay, simplistic story, and stunning environments.

reviewText:
Things Dark Souls 2 does better than Dark Souls 1:

- Performance. Runs like a dream on PC.
- Better bonfire placement, far far fewer boring walks over nothing fields and hallways to get back to the tough areas. Levels do not waste your time.
- Loads of weapons and armor, you can't go anywhere in this world without finding a dozen new weapons and bits of armor and spells to try
- Characters I don't want to murder. Except for Onion Bro and the Sun dude, Dark Souls 1's cast was full of gibbering half mad losers and incompetent idiots (And hell, Onion Bro and Sun dude are both incompetent themselves.). Dark Souls 2's characters are actually likeable without losing the Soulsian feel.
- Numerous, better PvP options.
- FINALLY trying to explain to people who don't go wiki their builds (All three of them.) that DEX does not make you faster, just that you hit harder with weapons that use DEX!

Things it does worse than Dark Souls 1:
- Level atmosphere. The empty space made Dark Souls 1 nearly impossible to replay without falling asleep but it sure helped craft a world. Dark Souls 2 does not have that feel at all.
- Soul Memory. Losing souls upon death now counts against your online rank even if you can't get them back. Of all the possible options for rebalancing online ranking, they could not possibly have picked a worse way to do it.
- Agility. Everything else in Souls has a stat, why not dodging? Well, because you don't explain it! You explained DEX and STR but not Agility? Get real From! Nobody will know that's why their dodging doesn't work.
- A really weak opening level. No Souls game has had a weak opening until Dark Souls 2.

reviewText:
Important: I bought the upgrade when it was 50% off. Price was 12,49e but when I logged in it said 2,49e. Not sure why. Just make sure you're logged in when buying the upgrade.

After playing both versions, it's easy to say that SotFS is what Dark Souls 2 should have been. Most fans of the series can play through the original game blindfolded. WIth Scholar they sort of cranked up the number of enemies and NPC invasions making careful approach more advised. For returning players, I recommend the Champions covenant for even harder experience. Places like Iron Keep will eat you alive.

reviewText:
Probably one of the best games I have ever played. It's an action RPG that takes place in an eerie world that feels utterly hopeless. The great thing about the gloomy atmosphere is the fact you feel very much a part of the world you're in and not necessarily the central foretold-hero-that-would-save-the-planet cliche.

The story is there but in a way that you sort of unravel what's happened as you play. At times you may need to look up on wiki pages to get a handle on things going unfolding around you, but that's normal for everyone. That being said, the story won't leave you completely in the dark, it's just a bit different in pacing and storytelling than conventional means.

If you'd like a challenge and want to play a refreshing RPG, I can't recommend this game enough. Initially I stopped playing two hours in and put the game away for a few months, but once I picked it up again out of boredom, I could not put it down. The game is a bit challenging as anyone with eyes have probably read from either game critics or â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ measuring forum posts, but don't let dying get to you. It is a lot like life in that failures will come and go, but once you start to adapt and become patient, you will ultimately start to see amazing progress in an unforgettable world.

This is certainly one of those games that is fun to discuss with friends after you play it.

People complain a lot about this one not being as good as the first.

Lets look at it differently:

Dark Souls 2 has all the visuals that we desired from the first. Sure it doesn't have the compelling story like its predecessor, nor an infamous character like Solaire, but all sequels have never been as popular as the first. Dark Souls 2 may not be the best game, but I don't regret a single minute I put into this game. The DLC's are all amazing, some of the battles being the toughest and most interesting throughout the game. The menus and massive amounts of armor choices are somewhat confusing, that would be my only complaint. All acheivments can be unlocked via NG++ just like the first, so it really isn't a let down like some players blow it up to be.

If you've heard bad things about this game, shrug them off and try it for yourself.

reviewText:
I have played and beat Dark Souls: Prepare to Die Edition and am a fan of the series. I have not played the original Dark Souls 2 that much so I can't compare Scholars of the First Sin to it. Anyways, SotFS is a remix of the original Dark Souls 2, with different enemy & item placements, changes to the level design and a new end boss. It comes with all the Dark Souls 2 DLCs. Controller is necessary because the Keyboard & Mouse controls are still garbage.

When starting the game you can choose different preset builds to suit your playstyle, just like the first DS game. Same different types of weapons and spells as the first game too but dark magic is now a thing called Hexes. Bonfires serve the same purpose as the first game as well except your weapons/armor are automatically repaired if they're not broken and you can fast travel right from the start. one thing that's different is that enemies will not respawn from sitting at a bonfire if you've killed them too many times, esentially forcing you to progress instead of farming or grinding. However you can burn these things called bonfires aesthetics that will make all the enemies and most treasure respawn but the difficulty will be increased in that area to a NG+ level of difficulty. Joining the Covenant of Champions will up the difficulty too but will make the enemies respawn indefinitely.

The game plays a little bit more faster than the first game, movements are quicker, enemies are too. Takes a while to get used to at first but it's an improvement. The game is not without it's flaws though. With fast travel being accessible so early in the game it's very convenient but also takes away from immersion since you don't have to play areas through from the opposite direction thus seeing less of it. That's actually more of a nitpick I guess. A lot of the enemy encounters seem to be poorly laid out and there just to annoy you but with them being able to despawn, you can just brute force your way through an area until all the enemies never come back, eliminating the challenge.

After beating it I still prefer the first Dark Souls over this one but I still think it's an awesome game.

As a huge fan of the series, I say that Dark Souls 2 is a good game. Despite being easier than its predecessors (Demon`s Souls (PS exclusive) and Dark Souls) it is still a very challenging game. The PvP is better than Dark Souls.
In my opinion:

Pros:
+ combat system + the first time you play dark souls or its predecessors it is noticible that combat is not underated as it is for exemple in Skyrim (which is a very good game too). Facing multiple enemies is an overwelming task, normally resulting in death. This is not a hack and slash game like Diablo, where you face 5 to 20 enemies and you hit 3 spells and obliterate them. Back to one of my favorite games...when you play skyrim you don`t feel the weapon impact on the enemy, it just slices through as if there isn`t an obstacle. But the Poise system and the game physics itself make you feel like you are in a true combat.
+ game difficulty + this game is hard ... not very hard and not even close to impossible where computer usually cheats to kill you. Therefore, you can have lots of fun trying to crawl your way through the game.
+ character versatility + you can create any kind of character ... a full plate warrior hold a great sword... a cleric casting heals and lightning bolts ... a naked guy casting spells... a rogue with light armor and backstabing... a caster with heavy armor ... ANYTHING ... people tend to use greatswords as you will see in multiplayer ... i think Freud explains
+ panoply of items + lots of cool items and spells ... good looking gear

Cons:
- PAUSE - this game DOES NOT pause. So you should expect some problems in real life when you just CAN`T let the joystick go. Thou i think this is fun, i died a couple of times because of this.
- the world -  i don`t know how to explain this. The cenario is fantastic and the atmosphere is CREEPY. But ... i don`t know something is missing... so i say ... imagine SKYRIM but with this game`s physics and an ominous atmhosphere.
- the NPCs - this is not my opinion ...but people always complain to me about this feature. They say the NPCs are miles high on LSD because dialog makes no sense. Some say that japanese dialog are novele-vague, just like their animes, don`t make sense. BUT... i think this is what the game proposes ... everyone you meet in the game is DEAD and LOOSING their minds... including you!

As a fan: play this game, but before, play Demon Soul`s

-Full review-


I have nothing but praise (the sun) for this game. What a fantastic and thrilling adventure. It grips you from the start and never lets go. Although the game can be stressful at times, especially when you're stuck on that one boss you've tried to beat a thousand times, it more than makes up for it the moment that you beat that boss or an area. It takes the brilliant qualities of Dark Souls (1) and improves upon them in many ways.

For one this game has such a mesmerising environment. Many times i found my self stepping back from the grind and just being awe struck at the beauty and detail thats went into this vast and exciting world. From the thrilling brilliance of the Sun on the sea in Majula to the eerily dark feel of the Black gulch's green glow, it has it all. The terrain were battles take place plays a more important role aswell with it being much easier to fall off a ledge or get backed into a corner and ive had my tumbles in this game with more than a few bosses and mobs, talking about you Dragonrider.

The mobs in this game accentuate the grand landscapes in this game with their impressive details and suiting characteristics. They're much more difficult in my opinion than this games predecossor and theres alot more of them than compared to the original Dark Souls 2. A few of them present a challenge to match that of a boss which emphasizes the difficulty of this game and adds to the relief when you finally beat an area. A memorable moment for me was getting chased by a million spiders in an attempt to fight their boss, the sheer panic and resolve i was feeling in that moment is a highlight for me in this game. They are beautiful in their own way and they fill their respective environment quite naturally and fit in with the characteristics of the boss they protect.

I found the bosses in this game very rewarding, particularly the DLC bosses. They were exceptionally designed and very challenging. Though the main theme in their deisign seemed to knight related there were a few that were outstanding such as The Dukes dear Freja. There are times when you're fighting that one grand boss and you can feel your heart racing and you find yourself drawing closer to the screen in such a tense moment trying to get that killing hit and when you finally beat it that wash of victory that comes over you makes all the struggling, all the blood, sweat and tears so worth it. And then its back to the grind for the next area.

The co-op in the game feels vastly more improved upon from the previous Dark Souls (1) introducing a new way to connect based on whats called soul memory. I liked the introduction of different types of summoned allies such as shades which expanded the range of help you can get. The PvP was exciting and many aspects of this games PvP match closely to that of Dark Souls (1) which meant you never lost your favrite covenant. There are alot of options and ways to go about PvP to make it accessible to a much larger amount of players.

There is a MASSIVE amount of weapons and armor in this game that cater to a great amount of fighting styles. They are very well contructed in how they look and how they behave in combat. There are the extreme forms of both heavy tank with 2 handed great hammer to nimble backstabber wielding 2 swift daggers with everything you can think of in between. I found the magic and spells in this game to be very elegent. There were alot to choose from for each individual style whether that be magnificent spells and angelic miracles to tenebrous hexes and wrathful pyromancies. They all add this sense of individuality to the game as you choose what your character is going to be.

The 'story' in this game requires attention to detail which can take a few play throughs to fully understand. I very much enjoyed my experience with this games story and it made me feel apart of its world. Plus i really liked option of 2 endings which i very much appreciated.

This fantastic game brought out so many great feelings from within me and although i got stressed, annoyed and angry they were all dwarfed by the explosion of happiness when i finally beat this game. No other game series quite captured that same affect for me making this one of the best games ive played.

If you're reading this i HIGHLY recommend you get this game, more so if you're a fan of RPG's and more so than that if you liked Dark Souls (1). Its different in quite a few ways from its predecessor but change isnt always a bad thing and this is a case were it was done right. Praise the Sun!

reviewText:
Dark Souls 2 is an action role-playing game set in an open environment. The game evolves around the player character who begins with a human who is cursed to always resurrect after dying. To break the curse, the undead travels to the fallen kingdom of Drangleic and is tasked by the Emerald Herald with obtaining four Great Souls from other powerful undead.

The game's plot is minimalistic, and varies based upon how much the player explores. There is little guidance and lack of direction given. The player must come to his/her intuition as to which path one must take, which can ultimately lead to a dead end, desired destination or even branching paths. Despite all this however, the plot is deeply ingrained in the essence of light and dark and how one cannot survive with the presence of one another.

This game is not just an ordinary casual RPG. It is an intense RPG for hardcore players who seek a challenge, as dying is frequent and bosses are abundant. To add to that, enemies deal a lot of damage and players must learn to time their blocks/parries, attacks as well as dodges rather than hack n' slashing. Save points (bonfires) are limited and scattered far from one another. The game evolves around the concept of using deaths to teach players to learn from their mistakes, as well as how to react in almost relentlessly hostile environments. From experience, there has not been many RPGs that has challenged me the way the Dark Souls series has. I must reiterate: this game is EXTREMELY difficult.

The button mapping and camera controls for keyboard is messy. If one were to consider buying this game, it is a PREREQUISITE to have a gamepad/controller or you will be in for a hard time. The graphics is not the best, but it is made up by the deep gameplay and non-stop action.

Overall, Dark Souls is a quality RPG game that challenges players to a new level. It's gameplay may be minimalistic and feel like a lack of direction, but it was designed in that manner to allow the player to unravel and uncover the deep story plot through thorough exploration. It is matched with sheer happiness and relief upon progress and completion. If adventure is to surprise and mystify you and invite you to uncover the secrets of a forgotten world, then Dark Souls is a great game for you. If entertainment is fun without failure and progress without pain, you'll have to find another game.

MORE on the actual expansion/DLC...
*Includes the three previously released DLC packs, Crown of the Sunken King, Crown of the Old Iron King, and Crown of the Ivory King.
- Additional NPCs added for an enhanced story experience.
- Parameter adjustments for improved game balance.
- Expanded item descriptions.
- Improved online matchmaking functionality.

- Additional upgrades to graphics, sound and performance.
- Increase in maximum online players in a single session (6 total).
- A complete revamp of character, enemy and item placement, which gives players a new experience.
- The Forlorn will hunt the player down throughout their journey. Their equipment can also be acquired by the player. These items include their Armor, Greatsword and Scythe.

reviewText:
I know many people dislike dark souls 2 and the scholar of the first sin version was just plain scummy, but I find it was a great introduction for me into the Souls series.

When I first saw Dark souls 2 sotfs (Scholar of the first sin) the only rpg's I had played were Twilight Princess, Skyward sword, and Skyrim, so all i thought of this game was that it was a difficult Legend of Zelda game with more emphasis on combat and you could change your gear. But oh how wrong I was, as with most people's experience playing a Souls game I found myself dying a lot though never really in the beginning, but somehow I never felt like giving up, soon enough I had learned the combat though I was playing with keyboard and mouse for my first playthrough.

One of my complaints is that the tutorial isn't really fun or engaging, and unlike the first Souls game it doesn't go strait up and tell you that it's going to be a difficult game that requires thought trial and error, quite the contrary actually it presents itself as easy and simple with slow yet engaging combat. This is one of my main complaints with the game, it does a poor job with the intro (Compared to Dark souls 1) despite all the beautiful environments it doesn't really prepare you much for the rest of the game gameplay-wise.

I can summarize the things the beginning teaches you into 4 things

1.if an enemy does something back away or block
2.when something looks dangerous don't go near it
3.summons help so find human effigies
4.things will ambush you, so if something looks dead hit it once

Despite what I say about the intro it is by no means terrible there are just a lot of things it could do better.

The next issue I have with this game is the bland design choices. Though most of the areas still look very nice they aren't creative or interesting With the exception of the dlc areas (I'll get to them later) and places like the dragon's aerie and the shrine of amana, in most areas the enemy designs are just humanoids of different sizes and armors. The areas feel linear and lazily done and unnaturally put together. Instead of feeling like a living breathing world it just feels like a generic fantasy world. Most of the areas though are fun to explore and have several secrets to make you go back to them.

One of my favorite things about this game though is the newly implemented mechanics (Except for soul memory and limited enemy spawns, they suck). Though I know many people will disagree with me, I prefer the rolling mechanics of ds2 and demon's souls to that of ds1, If you prefer to freely roll in any direction while locked on this game handles it very well I think. Dual wielding actually works (Though they never explain how in the game), It may not be exceptionally powerful but it can be fun to mess around with. The new gravity mechanics I find have been greatly improved with weight affecting the damage more. The new UI and durability though need to be reverted back to their original form in ds1 since they have become even more confusing than they already were.

The dlc is one of the better things in this game, though not as good as the Artorias of the abyss dlc for ds1 the dlc can provide some good fun. The areas and bosses (Except for The ancient explorer, Varg, and Cera) have cooler designs and are generally better than most in the base game (Though the enemies could still use some work) even though there are a lot of callbacks to ds1. The dlc's were one of my highlights while playing and you can definitely sink a lot of hours into them.

The story is good but the characters aren't too memorable and they all just seem depressed. There is definitely a huge expanse of lore to read in the item descriptions though they changed some in the sotfs version which was pretty scummy.

Now for a simple review i would rank it like this.

Gameplay 9/10
Design 7/10
Graphics 8/10
Story 8/10

Verdict 8.5/10

This game is good for someone who just wants to see what a Souls game is like and isn't all too familiar with dodge and block combat, or someone who has already played through ds1 and desperately craves more no matter the quality.

If you're familiar with games like these though i would skip ds2 and go play ds1.

reviewText:
I don't have many hours on record but that is because of crashes. I'm not happy about this, and other people get the same crashes and every effort to fix it has been attempted, but I'm still leaving positive feedback for the quality of the game and the fact that the vast majority of players don't experience these crashes. I played through maybe the first quarter of the game before the crashes became too irritating.

The game itself is one of the best games I have played for a very long time. The atmosphere is one of the best things about it, giving you great immersion and pulling you into the story right from the start. The challenging gameplay adds to this spooky atmosphere because you'll find that although the game is dark in nature, the main reason you will be scared is actually because you know you might die, not because of spooky monsters or music or anything. Veterans of souls games may find this experience differs as they know how to run through scenarios. In any case I love this atmosphere DESPITE the fact that I'm not generally into dark fantasy games.

The graphics I would give a solid 9/10. Great bloom effects and even though I notice that the texture quality on highest settings are slightly dated, the game does a good job in fooling you into believing you are playing a next-gen 2016 game by employing great use of shadows, blur, reflections and bloom effects. The other great thing about the graphics is that I feel that lower-mid tier PCs will be able to run this game no problem. The highest settings seem very light to run compared to other games, and you will be getting graphics quality which at a glance look to be toward the standard of games like GTA5, MGS5 etc, while being much less demanding on your GPU and CPU. I honestly don't understand how they managed to cram so much pristine graphics quality and effects into it with such efficiency.

However be prepared for the compatibility issues with certain graphics cards. If you have an AMD 7800series GPU I would avoid this game. I have also heard other complain with the same random graphics freezes so other cards may have issues with this game. This PC port issue is disappointing given how great this game generally is and you should give serious consideration to this before buying this game. I would only seriously recommend buying this game without any doubt, if you have two different options for machines, for example if you have both a desktop and a laptop, or if you have two graphics cards, etc.
(Believe me I have tried forcing dx9, reinstalling, verifying cache, disabling steam overlay, disabling GPU overclock, closing AMD settings UI, etc)

Pros:
Challenging and refreshing gameplay
Great graphics while still being light on your CPU/GPU
Pretty well thought out and unique levelling system
Long story
Good tutorial

Cons:
Compatibility issues with some hardware, causing crashes
Using consumable items to enter multiplayer/PvP doesn't make much sense

-Full review-


I have nothing but praise (the sun) for this game. What a fantastic and thrilling adventure. It grips you from the start and never lets go. Although the game can be stressful at times, especially when you're stuck on that one boss you've tried to beat a thousand times, it more than makes up for it the moment that you beat that boss or an area. It takes the brilliant qualities of Dark Souls (1) and improves upon them in many ways.

For one this game has such a mesmerising environment. Many times i found my self stepping back from the grind and just being awe struck at the beauty and detail thats went into this vast and exciting world. From the thrilling brilliance of the Sun on the sea in Majula to the eerily dark feel of the Black gulch's green glow, it has it all. The terrain were battles take place plays a more important role aswell with it being much easier to fall off a ledge or get backed into a corner and ive had my tumbles in this game with more than a few bosses and mobs, talking about you Dragonrider.

The mobs in this game accentuate the grand landscapes in this game with their impressive details and suiting characteristics. They're much more difficult in my opinion than this games predecossor and theres alot more of them than compared to the original Dark Souls 2. A few of them present a challenge to match that of a boss which emphasizes the difficulty of this game and adds to the relief when you finally beat an area. A memorable moment for me was getting chased by a million spiders in an attempt to fight their boss, the sheer panic and resolve i was feeling in that moment is a highlight for me in this game. They are beautiful in their own way and they fill their respective environment quite naturally and fit in with the characteristics of the boss they protect.

I found the bosses in this game very rewarding, particularly the DLC bosses. They were exceptionally designed and very challenging. Though the main theme in their deisign seemed to knight related there were a few that were outstanding such as The Dukes dear Freja. There are times when you're fighting that one grand boss and you can feel your heart racing and you find yourself drawing closer to the screen in such a tense moment trying to get that killing hit and when you finally beat it that wash of victory that comes over you makes all the struggling, all the blood, sweat and tears so worth it. And then its back to the grind for the next area.

The co-op in the game feels vastly more improved upon from the previous Dark Souls (1) introducing a new way to connect based on whats called soul memory. I liked the introduction of different types of summoned allies such as shades which expanded the range of help you can get. The PvP was exciting and many aspects of this games PvP match closely to that of Dark Souls (1) which meant you never lost your favrite covenant. There are alot of options and ways to go about PvP to make it accessible to a much larger amount of players.

There is a MASSIVE amount of weapons and armor in this game that cater to a great amount of fighting styles. They are very well contructed in how they look and how they behave in combat. There are the extreme forms of both heavy tank with 2 handed great hammer to nimble backstabber wielding 2 swift daggers with everything you can think of in between. I found the magic and spells in this game to be very elegent. There were alot to choose from for each individual style whether that be magnificent spells and angelic miracles to tenebrous hexes and wrathful pyromancies. They all add this sense of individuality to the game as you choose what your character is going to be.

The 'story' in this game requires attention to detail which can take a few play throughs to fully understand. I very much enjoyed my experience with this games story and it made me feel apart of its world. Plus i really liked option of 2 endings which i very much appreciated.

This fantastic game brought out so many great feelings from within me and although i got stressed, annoyed and angry they were all dwarfed by the explosion of happiness when i finally beat this game. No other game series quite captured that same affect for me making this one of the best games ive played.

If you're reading this i HIGHLY recommend you get this game, more so if you're a fan of RPG's and more so than that if you liked Dark Souls (1). Its different in quite a few ways from its predecessor but change isnt always a bad thing and this is a case were it was done right. Praise the Sun!

reviewText:
First off if you're already comfortable with the layout of enemies and items in the original DS2 be wary that all of this changes within Scholar. There are several positives for this gem if you're still interested, one being 60fps instead of DS2's sluggish 30fps, the new graphics of Scholar are undeniably better compared to the original game, the online community of Scholar is neck and neck with DS2 if not better, and the best part is Scholar includes all DLC with it's purchase.
The game itself has tons of replay value consisting of NG+, which causes more enemies in zones than your first playthrough, new item drops, and harder hitting enemies overall. Last but not least you have to read through 3 rules to help you survive the path to Drangleic.
1. trust all messages
2. Broken Thief Sword is the best wep
3. Git Gud
All and all, this game is a nice 9/10.

reviewText: What can be said about a game that makes you pull your hair out?  That it's one hell of a ride.  Dark Souls 2 like the original is very punishing when you make a mistake.  Some people scream it is unfair but I disagree.  The game is extremly fair, if you screw up you deserve every painful slash, stab, smash, burn, scratch, and trip to hollow-land that you get.  You will die, and you will die and you will die, but with each death you become that more adapt and vigilant.  This game requires you to make split second decisions on rather to play it safe or to run with everything you've got.  As much as regular enemies (which can kill you very easily) are a blast, the Bosses are that much more. They are huge, they are weird, and they are scary to even look at, not because its horror, but because you know with any mistake, you are dead.  Once you smite one of these monsters (there are many btw) you feel so overwhelmingly proud and accomplished at the same time.  No other game gives you that, no other game challenges you like that, no other game gets your heart pumping because you are moments away from victory or defeat.  No other game but Dark Souls.

reviewText:
*I'm no reviewer, I simply play games. Don't expect an in-depth Pros-Cons Review*



Demon's Souls, Dark Souls, Dark Souls 2. All great.



Long Thing:
The fanbase complains that this was a failed Souls because of a different director and it wasn't dark enough and whatever and whatnot. Too bad they didn't liked it, I personally enjoyed the living â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ out of it.

The changes in gameplay mechanics done here are great. A bit difficult to understand in the beginning, but definitely cool. Different.
After getting an Attribute to a certain level it felt horrible to keep leveling. Stamina comes to mind; after getting it to 20, every point you spend on it gives you only 1 extra number. Praise the Sun for some rings.
The fact that you can warp anywhere you've discovered before right from the beginning is a real pain saver.
They added new magic, Hex.
Covenants are cool, although Blue Sentinels is broken. Too bad.
I don't really know if this is new, but Maces bring death to heavy armored foes (I discovered it quite late).
They also added some new type of weapons, and hybrids.
The winks done to DS1, and the secret things are great (you now have to press X/A to open illusory walls).
Lore never fails. Gadamnit, I mean, LORE, what a fantastic thing.
The DLCs are also pretty cool. Kinda OP in my opinion, but after leveling a bit or gitting gud you're good to go.
I haven't really played Demon's in years, and I haven't really been much into PvP (my main focus is simply playing solo and helping others), but dueling in this game is great. Still needa git gud.
The above said, Combat overall feels like sugar.
Co-Op now works with a thing called soul Memory, not Levels. You can be a Level 150 (the PvP Meta) with 9kkSM or a Level 240 with 9kkSM.


This is the Souls game I've played the most (PS3 + PC). The more I play it, the more I like it.

It is with this Souls that I discovered the magnificence of making Builds. I usually played like whatever in the past Souls, but this one made me really get the hang of it (that's because I am a more mature man right now that when Demon's came out, and then DS1. It has nothing to do with DS2 being awesome. I have hair in my body).

Can't wait for DS3.

If you're thinking about buying the game, and happen to read this review, please:
-EXPLORE, you have no idea how many things you can miss.
-DON'T RUSH IT, give yourself time to avoid dying (even if the boss is 1 hit away from death)
-DURABILITY, weapons break after a number of swings. Have a couple extra in your inventory just in case.
-BE WARY OF GANKING, you'll be fighting 3+v1 every now and then.
-WEAKNESS: ROLLING, I've never gone turtle, but given a new Attribute in the Leveling System I consider rolling the ultimate thing.

EDIT: Forgot to mention you can Voice Chat now.



Short Thing:
I really liked this game.

reviewText:
I thoroughly enjoyed the Scholar of the First Sin edition.
The gameplay and feel were exactly like Dark Souls / Demon Souls.
Loved the multi-route options and the ability to skip optional bosses.
In this game edition, the developers had the foresight to add a large number of computer allies to support you, in the case where the co-op playerbase dwindled.

One major issue I had with the game was the the decision to limit the number of eligible players you could co-op with. You were limited to those who've only acquired a certain lifetime amount of 'currency' that was similar to your lifetime currency count. I felt this was a terrible decision as oftentimes you would permanently lose large amounts of spendible currency and these would still count towards your lifetime currency count. This meant that the more currency you lost, the weaker you were considered in relation to other players who didn't lose their currency. In the same thread, it meant that gaining too much currency blocked you from playing with the larger playerbase.

Despite the co-op matchmaking gripes. This game is a solid 10/10 for it's gameplay, simplistic story, and stunning environments.

reviewText:
Until FROMSOFT fix their horrible anti-cheat in DS3, I will never buy that game, nor will I complain about the shortcomings of DS2: SotFS.

Is it Dark Souls? Yes

Is it challenging? Perhaps not so much as the first, but that is due to a generally more fluid playing experience, especially during combat. Dodging, blocking, parrying, and all of that stuff just feels better here than it did in DS1, not that I disliked the way it was back then.

Is there a ton of content to explore? Oh yes, very much so, you will fall in love with Elyum Loyce.

Is there still an active community? You won't always struggle to find sunbros, or to get invaded, but it is certainly harder after DS3 came out.

Is it worth the buy?

Absolutely, I managed to get a ton of hours out of this game and still go back occasionally. Fans of the Souls series will have to take some time to get used to the changes here, but in the end, that's part of the fun. If you're like me and you don't want to get soft banned after spending $60 on DS3, spend $40 on this instead, it's well worth your time.
